Microporous Metal–Organic Framework with Lantern-like Dodecanuclear Metal Coordination Cages as Nodes for Selective Adsorption of C2/C1 Mixtures and Sensing of Nitrobenzene

    Microporous Metal–Organic Framework with Lantern-like Dodecanuclear Metal Coordination Cages as Nodes for Selective Adsorption of C2/C1 Mixtures and Sensing of Nitrobenzene

    • Yuan Chen†
      • , 
    • Ziyin Li†
      • , 
    • Qing Liu†
      • , 
    • Yangcan Shen†
      • , 
    • Xiuzhen Wu†
      • , 
    • Dandan Xu†
      • , 
    • Xiuling Ma†
      • , 
    • Lihua Wang†
      • , 
    • Qian-Huo Chen†
      • , 
    • Zhangjing Zhang*†‡
      • , and 
    • Shengchang Xiang*†‡
    View Author Information
    † Fujian Provincial Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials, Fujian Normal University, 32 Shangsan Road, Fuzhou, Fujian 350007, China
    ‡ State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, PR China
    *Z. Zhang. Tel: +86 15005999348. E-mail: zzhang@fjnu.edu.cn
    *S. Xiang. Tel: +86 15005999348. E-mail: scxiang@fjnu.edu.cn
    Cite this: Cryst. Growth Des. 2015, 15, 8, 3847–3852
    Publication Date (Web):June 25, 2015

    SUBJECTS:
    • Hydrocarbons,
    • Adsorption,
    Crystal Growth & Design
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A microporous metal–organic framework (FJU-12), {[Cd12(Trz)8(DMF)2(H2O)4](BDC)9}·2(Me2NH2)·4DMF·16H2O (Trz = 1,2,4-triazole, BDC = terephthalic acid, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), was rationally constructed using unprecedented lantern-like 1,2,4-triazole-based dodecanuclear metal coordination cages as supermolecular building blocks. After activation, FJU-12a exhibits highly selective adsorption of C2 compound/CH4 mixtures and efficient sensing of nitrobenzene (NB). The selectivity (79.7) of C2H2/CH4 is comparable to the most selective Cu-TDPAT (82, TDPAT = 2,4,6-tris(3,5-dicarboxylphenylamino)-1,3,5-triazine).

    Synopsis

    A microporous metal−organic framework (FJU-12) was rationally constructed with unprecedented 1,2,4-triazole-based dodecanuclear metal coordination cages nodes, exhibiting highly selective adsorption of C2s/CH4 mixtures and efficient sensing to nitrobenzene.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Considerable attention on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with high-nuclearity clusters as supermolecular building units (SBUs) for chemists stems from their intriguing structural versatility and promising multifunctional properties.(1) The high-nuclearity cluster SBUs can contribute to construction of novel topological types with high-connected networks,(2) to prevention of structural interpenetration and thus increase of porosity of the framework, and even to endowing the framework with its intrinsic nature to realize interesting multifunctional materials. As the popular organic linkers, such as aromatic carboxylates and N-containing ligands, are limited by their low coordination numbers, there are two avenues to construct such high-nuclearity-cluster based MOFs: one is to presynthesize dendritic poly(carboxylic acid)s for the MOFs with metal–organic polyhedra SBUs;(3) another is to employ some extra small anions or molecules showing high coordination numbers, such as 1,2,3-triazole,(4) thioalcohol,(5) halogen,(6) PO43–,(6) SO42–,(7) CO32–,(8) ClO4–,(9) formate,(10) and pyrazole,(11) as cluster-forming ligands. Several MOFs based on tetra-,(12) penta-,(4a, 13) hexa-,(14) hepta-,(4b, 15) and octanuclear(7, 16) cluster SBUs with permanent porosity and appealing adsorption capacity have been explored, but those containing higher nuclearity are rarely reported.(6, 11) To construct such MOFs still remains challenging.
    Herein, a strategy with 1,2,4-triazole as cluster forming agents is proposed to target a uninodal 8-connected MOF, {[Cd12(Trz)8(DMF)2(H2O)4](BDC)9}·2(Me2NH2)·4DMF·16H2O (Trz = 1,2,4-triazole, BDC = terephthalic acid, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) (FJU-12), with unprecedented lantern-like dodecanuclear cadmium metal coordination cages as SBUs. After activation, FJU-12a exhibits highly selective sorption toward C2 compound/CH4 mixtures and efficient sensing of NB.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References

    Materials and Measurements

    All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) was performed on a METTLER TGA/SDTA 851 analyzer under nitrogen atmosphere with heating rate of 10 K/min from 30 to 600 °C. FT-IR spectrum of the synthesized complex was carried out on a Nicolet 5700 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets. Elementary analysis was collected on a Vario EL III elementary analyzer to give a ratio of C, H, and N. X-ray powder diffraction data was recorded on a Rigaku MultiFlex diffractometer at 40 kV, 40 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) with a scan speed of 2 deg/min.

    Synthesis of FJU-12

    Terephthalic acid (0.1 mmol, l6.6 mg) was dissolved in DMF (5 mL) using ultrasound, and then, 1,2,4-triazole (0.1 mmol, 6.9 mg), Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.1 mmol, 29.8 mg), NaClO4 (5.0 mg) and 1.0 mL of distilled water were added to the transparent solution. Ultimately, the resulting transparent solution was sealed in a glass bottle, which was heated at 100 °C for 24 h. After reaction, colorless flaky crystals were obtained. Elemental Analysis for C55H75Cd6N16O31 (%) Calcd: C 30.32, H 3.45, N 10.30. Found: C 29.03, H 3.600, N 10.59.

    Single Crystal X-ray Structure Determination

    Data collection and structural analysis of crystal FJU-12 were collected on an Agilent Technologies SuperNova single crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). The crystal was kept at 99.99(10) K during data collection. Using Olex2,(17) the structure was solved with the Superflip structure solution program using Charge Flipping and refined with the ShelXL(18) refinement package using least squares minimization. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms on the ligands were placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. We employed PLATON(19) and SQUEEZE(20) to calculate the diffraction contribution of the solvent molecules and thereby produce a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The detailed crystallographic data are shown in Supplementary Tables S2–S4, Supporting Information (CCDC 1047491).

    Gas Sorption Measurements

    After the bulk of the solvent was decanted, the freshly prepared sample of FJU-12 (∼0.15 g) was soaked in ∼10 mL of methanol for 1 h, and then the solvent was decanted. Following the procedure of methanol soaking and decanting 10 times, the solvent-exchanged samples were activated by vacuum at room temperature overnight (∼10 h) until a pressure of 5 μmHg. N2, CO2, methane, ethylene, ethane, and acetylene adsorption isotherms were measured on Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 surface area analyzer for the activated FJU-12a. The sorption measurement was maintained at 77 K with liquid nitrogen and at 273 K with an ice–water bath (slush). A water bath of 22.5 was used for adsorption isotherms at 296 K, whereas dry ice–acetone and ice–water baths were used for the isotherms at 195 and 273 K, respectively.

    Virial Equation Analysis

    The virial equation can be written(21, 22) as follows:(1)where n is the amount adsorbed (mol g–1) gas at pressure p (Pa). At low surface coverage, the A2 and higher terms can be neglected, and the equation becomes(2)A linear graph of ln(n/p) versus n is obtained at low surface coverage, and this is consistent with neglecting higher terms in eq 2. A0 quantifies the adsorbate–adsorbent interactions, while A1 is related to adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. The virial parameters are given in Table S1, Supporting Information.

    Enthalpies of Adsorption

    Zero Surface Coverage

    The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption at zero surface coverage (Qst,n=0) are a fundamental measure of adsorbate–adsorbent interactions, and these values were obtained from the A0 values obtained by extrapolation of the virial graph to zero surface coverage.

    Van’t Hoff Isochore

    The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption as a function of surface coverage were calculated from the isotherms using the van’t Hoff isochore, which is given by the following equation:(3)A graph of ln P versus 1/T at constant amount adsorbed (n) allows the isosteric enthalpy and entropy of adsorption to be determined. The pressure values for a specific amount adsorbed were calculated from the adsorption isotherms by the following methods: (1) assuming a linear relationship between adjacent isotherm points starting from the first isotherm point; (2) using the virial equation at low surface coverage. The agreement between the two methods is shown in Figure S5, Supporting Information.

    Prediction of the Gas Adsorption Selectivity by IAST

    The measured experimental data on pure component isotherms for CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 at 273 and 296 K were converted to absolute loadings usingwhere Z is the compressibility factor, which was estimated by Peng–Robinson equation of state. The accessible pore volume within the materials, Vpore, is taken to be equal to the experimentally determined value (cm3 g–1) using the following formula:(4)The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was used to predict the binary mixture adsorption from the experimental pure-gas isotherm. The accuracy of IAST for the estimation of the binary mixture equilibrium in different zeolites(23) and MOFs(24) has already been established in a number of published papers. In order to perform the integrations required by IAST, the single-component isotherms should be fitted by a proper model. We found for this set of data that the single-site Langmuir–Freundlich equation was successful in fitting the data.Here, P is the pressure of the bulk gas at equilibrium with the adsorbed phase (kPa), N is the adsorbed amount per mass of adsorbent (mmol/g), Nmax is the saturation capacities of sites 1 (mmol/g), b is the affinity coefficients of sites 1 (1/kPa), and n represents the deviations from an ideal homogeneous surface. The fitted parameters were then used to predict multicomponent adsorption with IAST. The adsorption selectivities based on IAST for mixed C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 are defined by the following equation:where Xi is the mole fraction of component i (i = 1, 2) in the adsorbed phases and Yi is the mole fraction of component i in bulk phases.

    Fluorescence Measurements

    The photoluminescence (PL) spectra of activated FJU-12a and solvent-loaded FJU-12a were investigated in the solid state at room temperature and recorded by a Horiba FluoroMax-4 fluorescence spectrometer. The samples were put into a homemade clamp composed of three pieces of commercial quartz slides of dimensions 20 mm × 37 mm × 1 mm. The middle slide had a hole of dimensions 3 mm × 5 mm × 1 mm in its center for hosting the tested sample. In order to effectively minimize the error of different peak intensities caused by thickness and morphology of the tested samples, the hole was fully filled with the ground powder of the outgassed (or solvent-loaded) samples FJU-12a (∼5.0 mg) with the particle size of 80–100 mesh. Various solvent-loaded samples were prepared by introducing FJU-12a powder into 2.0 mL of THF, methanol, acetone, dichloromethane, chloroform, and nitrobenzene (NB), respectively. For NB sensing experiments, activated FJU-12 powder was dispersed in THF with different concentrations of NB.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References

    Description of the Crystal Structure

    FJU-12 was synthesized via solvothermal reaction of aqueous dimethylformamide (DMF) solution of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, NaClO4, Trz, and terephthalic acid (H2BDC) at 100 °C for 1 day. It was formulated as {[Cd12(Trz)8(DMF)2(H2O)4](BDC)9}·2(Me2NH2)·4DMF·16H2O by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the phase purity of the bulk material was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S11, Supporting Information). X-ray structural analysis reveals that FJU-12 has a 3D open framework structure containing centrosymmetric dodecanuclear metal coordination cages [Cd12(Trz)8(Osolvent)6(CO2)18] (Figure 1b) in which 12 Cd ions are linked by eight bridging carboxylate groups and eight Trz ligands in μ1,2,4 fashion to form a lantern-like SBU. Each dodecanuclear metal coordination cage links to eight neighboring SBUs via 18 BDC ligands to give a 3D eight-connected hex topological net with Schläfli symbol of {36·418·53·6}(25) (Figure 1f).
    The 3D open framework of FJU-12 has two kinds of cages (Figure 1b,c). The small one is the lantern-like metal coordination cage of 5.1 Å in diameter with the aperture of 2.9 × 3.6 Å2. The large one consists of eight dodecanuclear metal coordination cages and 18 BDC ligands with diameter of 9.4 Å and windows in dimensions of 3.3 × 9.6 Å2 and 4.7 × 9.8 Å2. The calculated free volume in fully desolvated structure FJU-12 is 54.9% by PLATON(26) (11051.6 Å3 of the 20113.3 Å3 unit cell volume).

    Gas Sorption Properties

    To check the porosity of FJU-12, the fresh sample was guest-exchanged with anhydrous methanol and then activated under high vacuum at 296 K to generate the desolvated FJU-12a. Compared with the as-synthesized sample, the peak positions in the PXRD of activated FJU-12a shift to higher 2θ values (Figure S11, Supporting Information), suggesting the framework shrinks after removal of guest molecules, which also demonstrates the flexible nature of FJU-12. The porosity was characterized by N2 gas sorption at 77 K (Figure S6, Supporting Information) with an apparent BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of 95.3 m2/g and 132.1 m2/g, respectively. CO2 adsorption at 196 K was also used to characterize the porosity. As shown in Figure 2a, the BET and Langmuir surface areas calculated from adsorption isotherms are 136.2 and 211.0 m2/g, respectively, within the pressure range of 0.05 < P/P0 < 0.35 (Figure S8, Supporting Information). The higher surface areas calculated from CO2 adsorption at 196 K than those from N2 adsorption at 77 K suggest a certain degree of shrinkage for the activated framework, which is consistent with the result of the PXRD. Nevertheless, FJU-12a still shows permanent porosity with total pore volume of 0.084 cm3/g from the highest adsorption values of 44.39 cm3/g (CO2). To the best of our knowledge, only a few MOFs with higher nuclearity cluster nodes than 8 have permanent porosity.(6, 11)
    Establishment of the porosity of FJU-12a encouraged us to explore its potential application in C2/C1 adsorption and separation,(27, 28) and the adsorption of these gases on FJU-12a at 296 and 273 K were investigated. Separation of C2 hydrocarbons (C2s) from methane (C1) is a very important industrial process. This is because the recovery of C2 hydrocarbons from methane not only upgrades the quality of natural gas for its efficient usage but can also provide an alternative chemical source of C2s for further chemical processing and transformation. As shown in Figure 2b and Figure S7, Supporting Information, FJU-12a takes up many more C2s than CH4; for example, FJU-12a takes up acetylene, ethylene, and ethane of 19.59, 14.49, and 13.76 cm3/g, respectively, which are 4.6, 3.9, and 3.2 times higher than CH4 (4.28 cm3/g) at 296 K and 1 bar, suggesting that FJU-12a is a promising material for highly selective separation toward C2/C1 mixtures.
    The Henry’s law selectivities for acetylene, ethylene, and ethane over methane at 296 K are 31.9, 16.0, and 20.7, respectively, which were calculated based on the equation Si/CH4 = KH(i)/KH(CH4), are higher than many reported MOFs (Table S5, Supporting Information). The well-defined ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST)(29) of Myers and Prausnitz is also employed to evaluate the C2s/CH4 separation selectivities. Figure S10, Supporting Information, shows the IAST calculations of the adsorption selectivity for equimolar C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 mixtures at 296 K in FJU-12a. The selectivities of C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 with respect to CH4 are 79.7, 26.4, and 30.3, respectively, by IAST at 296 K and pressures up to 100 kPa. It is worth noting that the adsorption selectivity of C2H2/CH4 is comparable to the most selective Cu-TDPAT (82, TDPAT = 2,4,6-tris(3,5-dicarboxylphenylamino)-1,3,5-triazine) (Table S6, Supporting Information), indicating that FJU-12a is a potential selective separation material for C2s/CH4.
    In order to establish why FJU-12a exhibits such a highly selective separation for C2s/CH4, its coverage dependent adsorption enthalpies were calculated on the basis of the virial method and the van’t Hoff isochore. The virial graphs for adsorption of these gases on FJU-12a at 273 and 296 K are shown in Figures S1–S4, Supporting Information. The comparison of the results from the two methods, the linear extrapolation and the virial equation, shows a very good agreement (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The enthalpies at zero coverage are 29.2, 22.7, and 21.0 kJ/mol for C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6, respectively, which are larger than that for CH4 (14.7 kJ/mol). The higher uptakes for C2 hydrocarbons than methane may be ascribed to the following two reasons: First, the first virial coefficient A0 is related to the Henry’s law constant KH by the equation KH = exp(A0), which reflects the adsorbate–adsorbent interactions. The A0 values of CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 show that KH(C2H2), KH(C2H4), and KH(C2H6) are higher than KH(CH4), indicating stronger adsorbate–adsorbent interactions for C2s especially for C2H2. The second virial parameter (A1) is a function of adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. The differences in A1 are statistically significant for CH4, C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 indicating lower repulsion energies between neighbors for C2s than that for CH4.(22, 30) Second, the higher uptakes for C2 hydrocarbons might be due to the comparable pore sizes in FJU-12a with these smaller C2 molecules, ultimately, leading to highly selective adsorption of C2 over C1 hydrocarbons at room temperature.

    Fluorescence and Sensing Properties

    Activated FJU-12 for luminescence and sensing studies is investigated. The emission peak of FJU-12a was around 435 nm when monitored at 325 nm. To examine the potential of FJU-12a for sensing of small molecules, its fluorescence properties in different solvents were investigated. As shown in Figure 3a, its photoluminescence spectrum is largely dependent on the solvent molecules, particularly in the cases of THF and NB, giving the most significant enhancing and quenching effects, respectively. Such solvent-dependent luminescence properties are of interest for sensing of NB molecules, as demonstrated in some pioneering works done by Li’s group.(31) Detection of NB is important because NB is the basic constituent of nitroaromatic explosives and is also a notorious environmental pollutant.(31, 32) When NB content was gradually added to THF solvent, the fluorescence was gradually decreased with the addition of NB solvent (Figure 3b). The luminescence quenching efficiency was analyzed by fitting the experimental data to the Stern–Volmer equation, (I0/I) = KSV[M] + 1, in which I0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of the analyte, [M] is the molar concentration of the analyte, and KSV is the quenching constant (M–1). The ratio (I0/I) of the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of NB was approximately linearly increased with increasing the concentration of NB (Figure 3b). The Stern–Volmer plot of luminescent intensity (I0/I) vs the concentration of NB is shown in Figure 3b. The Stern–Volmer constant (KSV) was 35 M–1 for NB. Such quenching effect should be attributed to the charge transfer electron transitions from the FJU-12 framework to NB due to the electron-deficient property of NB and the π–π interactions between FJU-12a framework and NB molecules.(33) The encouraging result reveals that FJU-12a could be a promising luminescent probe for detecting NB.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusions
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    In summary, we have synthesized a novel three-dimensional uninodal hex net FJU-12 based on an unprecedented lantern-like dodecanuclear Cd coordination cage. FJU-12a exhibits high selectivity for the separation of C2 hydrocarbons from methane. The selectivities of C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 with respect to CH4 are 79.7, 26.4, and 30.3, respectively, by IAST at 296 K and pressures up to 100 kPa. It is worth noting that the adsorption selectivity of C2H2/CH4 of 79.7 is comparable to the most selective Cu-TDPAT (82). In addition, FJU-12a has the potential for sensing of small molecules especially for NB, giving the most significant quenching effects. It is expected that this work highlights the promise of FJU-12 for important separation of C2/C1 mixtures and highly sensitive sensors for NB in the future.

      1a
      A luminescent microporous metal-organic framework for the fast and reversible detection of high explosives
      Lan, Anjian; Li, Kunhao; Wu, Haohan; Olson, David H.; Emge, Thomas J.; Ki, Woosoek; Hong, Maochun; Li, Jing
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (13), 2334-2338CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A highly luminescent microporous metal-org. framework, [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpee)] (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; bpee = 1,2-bipyridylethene), was prepd., characterized by X-ray crystallog., and found to be capable of very fast and reversible detection of the vapors of the nitroarom. explosive 2,4-dinitrotoluene and the plastic explosive taggant 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane through redox fluorescence quenching with unprecedented sensitivity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkt1yqtb8%253D&md5=d02d4635719a0cae1e9d3a610a9645fb
      (b) Yuan, D.-Q.; Zhao, D.; Sun, D.-F.; Zhou, H.-C. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2010, 49, 5357 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201001009
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1b
      An Isoreticular Series of Metal-Organic Frameworks with Dendritic Hexacarboxylate Ligands and Exceptionally High Gas-Uptake Capacity
      Yuan, Daqiang; Zhao, Dan; Sun, Daofeng; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (31), 5357-5361, S5357/1-S5357/12CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      An isoreticular metal-org. framework series with the (3,24)-connected network topol. has been synthesized by using a series of dendritic hexacarboxylate ligands. The framework is stabilized by incorporating microwindows whose size is fixed by the formation of cuboctahedral supported by the isophthalate moieties throughout the framework. Adsorption studies using hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide reveal that they have close to record-high gas adsorption capacities.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXptlWgurg%253D&md5=27ba1f52c8f37d92c3ba30a8673b7654
      (c) Suh, M. P.; Park, H. J.; Prasad, T. K.; Lim, D.-W. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 782 DOI: 10.1021/cr200274s
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1c
      Hydrogen Storage in Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Suh, Myunghyun Paik; Park, Hye Jeong; Prasad, Thazhe Kootteri; Lim, Dae-Woon
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 782-835CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. MOFs have versatile structures, high surface areas and high pore vols. - they can be regarded as good candidate materials for H storage. There are many MOFs that have high H adsorption capacities at low temps., typically at 77 or 87 K. The highest H storage capacity reported so far is 99.5 mg/g at 77K and 56 bar for NU-100. However, the high H capacities of MOFs at cryogenic temps. decrease as the temp. increases to room temp. This is because the H adsorption in MOFs is weak physisorption and the interaction energies between the H mols. and frameworks are low. To develop MOFs as H storage materials that meet the U.S.DOE targets for an on-board hydrogen system, a serious challenge is still present in the design and synthesis of the MOF materials. We may expect that highly stable MOFs having a large surface area and pore vol., together with many open metal sites and embedded catalysts for hydrogen spillover, would provide some pos. results for H storage at ambient temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1GlsbjM&md5=dd1f08beefd27cce77d88e466551c1af
      (d) Kreno, L. E.; Leong, K.; Farha, O. K.; Allendorf, M.; Van Duyne, R. P.; Hupp, J. T. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 1105 DOI: 10.1021/cr200324t
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1d
      Metal-Organic Framework Materials as Chemical Sensors
      Kreno, Lauren E.; Leong, Kirsty; Farha, Omar K.; Allendorf, Mark; Van Duyne, Richard P.; Hupp, Joseph T.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 1105-1125CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The authors present a crit. review of the literature on metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) as chem. sensors. The authors begin by briefly examg. challenges relating to MOF sensor development including the design of MOFs with desirable properties, incorporation of appropriate signal transduction capabilities, and integration of MOFs into devices by employing thin-film growth techniques. Subsequent sections discuss specific examples of MOF sensors, categorized by method of signal transduction. Sensors based on MOF photoluminescence are discussed briefly. The authors have limited the review of luminescence-based sensors to a small no. of recent reports where the porous MOF architecture, or its chem. compn., imparts selective sensing capabilities. Scintillating MOFs that luminesce in the presence of radioactive analytes are also discussed. Other signal transduction schemes that use photons include various kinds of optical interferometry, analyte modulation of localized surface plasmon resonance energies, and solvatochromism. Mech. signal-transduction schemes employed with MOFs include ones based on surface acoustic wave, quartz crystal microbalance, and microcantilever devices. Elec. schemes thus far were limited to ones based on impedance spectroscopy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVCgtL%252FI&md5=f6ed572725bc067ee8da81880bf1ec90
      (e) Li, J.-R.; Sculley, J.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 869 DOI: 10.1021/cr200190s
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1e
      Metal-Organic Frameworks for Separations
      Li, Jian-Rong; Sculley, Julian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 869-932CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. This article reviews the metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous solid materials. Their performances for applications in sepns. and purifications is attracting intense interest of researchers working in the fields of chem., chem. engineering, materials science, and others. Despite being in its infancy, the research progress in this subject has already shown that MOFs are promising for sepn. applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1OnsbbL&md5=635f36e2682f7fbc651f5021d591a1cf
      (f) Yoon, M.; Srirambalaji, R.; Kim, K. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 1196 DOI: 10.1021/cr2003147
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1f
      Homochiral Metal-Organic Frameworks for Asymmetric Heterogeneous Catalysis
      Yoon, Minyoung; Srirambalaji, Renganathan; Kim, Kimoon
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 1196-1231CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The authors have provided an overview of metal-org. framework (MOF)-based asym. heterogeneous catalysis by presenting the state of the art in this field and discussing its potential and limitations. Here, MOF-based asym. catalysts are classified according to their working principles and synthetic strategies. Design, synthesis and structural characteristics of chiral metal-org. frameworks, as well as their catalytic activities in various asym. transformations, are described.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVOlt7rF&md5=7ee0508d7ed4b69aec1ca6d950681972
      (g) Lin, Z.-J.; Lü, J.; Hong, M.-C.; Cao, R. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2014, 43, 5867 DOI: 10.1039/C3CS60483G
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1g
      Metal-organic frameworks based on flexible ligands (FL-MOFs): structures and applications
      Lin, Zu-Jin; Lu, Jian; Hong, Maochun; Cao, Rong
      Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5867-5895CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers (CPs), are cryst. materials constructed from metal ions or clusters bridged by org. ligands to form one-, two-, or three-dimensional infinite networks. In contrast with the prolific prodn. of MOFs based on rigid ligands (RL-MOFs), the design, syntheses and applications of MOFs based on flexible ligands (FL-MOFs) are somewhat overlooked. Although sacrificing a measure of control, the use of flexible ligands may provide unique opportunities to obtain novel cryst. framework materials exhibiting desirable attributes. In this review, emphasis has been placed on the design and the structural diversity of FL-MOFs. Homochiral FL-MOFs and dynamic frameworks induced by flexible ligands are also briefly outlined. An overview is also shown for the applications of FL-MOFs as platforms for gas adsorption, heterogeneous catalysis, proton conduction etc.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1Slu7jI&md5=f9d627b8f4766621b92cad2116e13e11
      (h) Zhang, Z.-J.; Yao, Z.-Z.; Xiang, S.-C.; Chen, B. Energy Environ. Sci. 2014, 7, 2868 DOI: 10.1039/C4EE00143E
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1h
      Perspective of microporous metal-organic frameworks for CO2 capture and separation
      Zhang, Zhangjing; Yao, Zi-Zhu; Xiang, Shengchang; Chen, Banglin
      Energy & Environmental Science (2014), 7 (9), 2868-2899CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. It is emergent to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion and thereby limit climate destabilization. In order to achieve the industrial scenario of CCS, there is a need for the discovery of better solid CO2 adsorbents that realize great improvement of selective capacity and stability to moisture as well as significant redns. in energy requirements and costs. In this review, we provide an overview of the current status of the emerging microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) for the storage and sepn. of carbon dioxide. We summarize the main factors for CO2 capture performance of MOF materials under different working conditions, in comparison with those for zeolite materials. At the same time, we analyze the relationship among porous structures, pore/window sizes, capacity, selectivity and enthalpy of porous MOFs for CCS, which will give us clues for the design and synthesis of MOF materials as CO2 adsorbents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtVymu7rI&md5=6b2caf35f3003cc10e1eba706bca4519

      2a
      Metal-organic replica of fluorite built with an eight-connecting tetranuclear cadmium cluster and a tetrahedral four-connecting ligand
      Chun, Hyungphil; Kim, Dongwoo; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Kimoon
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (8), 971-974CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A non-interpenetrating 3-dimensional metal-org. framework, [Cd4(TCPM)2(DMF)4]·4DMF·4H2O, synthesized by a solvothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate and the tetracarboxylate ligand tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)methane (TCPM), is the 1st metal-org. analog of fluorite (CaF2). In the structure of the title compd. an eight-connecting tetranuclear cadmium cluster and a tetracarboxylate ligand play the role of Ca2+ and F- ions, resp., in fluorite.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      2b
      Twelve-connected net with face-centered cubic topology: a coordination polymer based on [Cu12(μ4-SCH3)6]6+ clusters and CN- linkers
      Li, Dan; Xiao, Ping; Zhou, Rui; Huang, Xiao-Chun
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (27), 4175-4178CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A microporous coordination polymer based on a dodecanuclear copper(I) cluster, [Cu12(μ4-SCH3)6(CN)6]·2H2O, as a twelve-connected node was synthesized by a simultaneous redox, sulfurization, and self-assembly reaction under solvothermal conditions and characterized by x-ray crystallog. The synthesis provides a model reaction to simulate the transformation of inorg. sulfur into org. sulfur.

      2c
      Two unprecedented 10-connected bct topological metal-organic frameworks constructed from cadmium clusters
      Song, Wei-Chao; Pan, Qinhe; Song, Peng-Chao; Zhao, Qiang; Zeng, Yong-Fei; Hu, Tong-Liang; Bu, Xian-He
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2010), 46 (27), 4890-4892CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      By simply modifying the expansion of ligand tether length, two Cd(ii) metal-org. frameworks have been constructed from linear tetranuclear and trinuclear cadmium clusters, resp., which present an unprecedented 10-connected unimodal bct net.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXotFentrw%253D&md5=5330e837573c66ab29589f873d86af1f

      2d
      Co5/Co8-Cluster-Based Coordination Polymers Showing High-Connected Self-Penetrating Networks: Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Magnetic Properties
      Li, Dong-Sheng; Zhao, Jun; Wu, Ya-Pan; Liu, Bin; Bai, Liang; Zou, Kun; Du, Miao
      Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (14), 8091-8098CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two novel Co(II)-cluster-based coordination polymers, [Co5(μ3-OH)2(1,4-ndc)4(bix)2]n (1) and {[Co8(μ3-OH)4(1,4-ndc)6(btp)(H2O)6]·H2O}n (2), were prepd. by hydrothermal reactions of cobalt(II) perchlorate with 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2ndc) and different N-donor coligands (bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene and btp = 4,4'-bis(triazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl). In 1, 10-connected [Co5(μ3-OH)2(COO)8] clusters are extended by the μ4-1,4-ndc2- and trans-bix ligands to construct a rare, self-penetrating ile framework that can interestingly be regarded as the cross-link of two interpenetrating 6-connected pcu networks. For 2, [Co8(μ3-OH)4(COO)12] clusters serve as the 8-connected nodes, which are bridged by the μ4/μ5-1,4-ndc2- and trans-btp ligands to afford the highest-connected uninodal self-penetrating (420.68) network based on octacobalt clusters. A synthetic and structural comparison of 1 and 2 demonstrates that the features of auxiliary N-donor ligands play a key role in governing the in situ formed clusters and the final 3-dimensional coordination frameworks. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that complex 1 shows an antiferromagnetic interaction between the adjacent Co(II) ions, whereas 2 displays the dominant antiferromagnetic exchanges in 300-50 K and a ferrimagnetic-like behavior at lower temps.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtVCgs7%252FP&md5=8d034c3e658da9ba4bafb2a149ef8ded
      (e) Song, X.-Z.; Song, S.-Y.; Zhao, S.-N.; Hao, Z.-M.; Zhu, M.; Meng, X.; Zhang, H.-J. Dalton Trans. 2013, 42, 8183 DOI: 10.1039/c3dt50687h
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2e
      Two High-connected Metal-organic Frameworks Based on d10-metal Clusters: Syntheses, Structural Topologies and Luminescent Properties
      Song, Xue-Zhi; Song, Shu-Yan; Zhao, Shu-Na; Hao, Zhao-Min; Zhu, Min; Meng, Xing; Zhang, Hong-Jie
      Dalton Transactions (2013), 42 (23), 8183-8187CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The d10-metal-oxo clusters connected by the asym. tricarboxylate and linear neutral ligands give rise to two novel high-connected MOFs. Complexes {[Zn2L(μ-OH)(4,4'-bpy)0.5]H2O}n (1) and {[Cd2L(μ-OH)(4,4'-bpy)]H2O}n (2) (L = biphenyl-3,3',5-tricarboxylate) feature the highest (3,16)- and (3,8)-connected three-dimensional frameworks based on cube-like octanuclear [Zn8(μ2-OH)4(CO2)12] clusters and butterfly-like tetranuclear [Cd4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6] clusters as the secondary building units, resp.

      2f
      Pillared-Layer Cluster Organic Frameworks Constructed from Nanoscale Ln10 and Cu16 Clusters
      Fang, Wei-Hui; Yang, Guo-Yu
      Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (11), 5631-5636CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two pillared-layer cluster org. frameworks, [Ln5(μ3-OH)4(μ-H2O)Cu8I8L11]·H2O (L = 4-pyridin-4-ylbenzoate; Ln = Dy (1), Eu (2)), were made by employing lanthanide oxide and copper(I) halide as the source of lanthanide and transitional metal under hydrothermal condition. Compared to the pillared-layer frameworks constructed from heterometallic layers and org. pillars, these two compds. are derived from lanthanide cluster org. layers and copper(I) halide cluster motifs. Thus, there are two distinct types of inorg. metal connectors in the structure, one is hydroxo lanthanide [Ln10(μ3-OH)8]22+ (Ln10) cluster, and the other is copper(I) halide [Cu16I16] (Cu16) cluster. The rational assembly of these two inorg. connectors and org. linear linkers gives the two complexes here. They appear to be the first 3D frameworks constructed from decanuclear hydroxo lanthanide clusters. From the topol. point of view, these compds. represent an intriguing example of a binodal (8,14)-connected net considering the Ln10 and Cu16 connectors as the nodes, revealing that they are typical high dimensional frameworks with high connected net based on high nuclearity nodes. Also, elemental anal., IR, TGA, PXRD, and UV-visible properties are also studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXotVeksbk%253D&md5=075342c05813c0165d06fef8902d4cd5

      3a
      High H2 adsorption in a microporous metal-organic framework with open metal sites
      Chen, Banglin; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Millward, Andrew R.; Contreras, Damacio S.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (30), 4745-4749CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A copper-based metal-org. framework (MOF) has been synthesized, and its structure has been solved by X-ray crystallog. The remarkably high hydrogen adsorption properties (2.47 wt%) of this compd. have been studied.

      3b
      A Metal-Organic Framework with Entatic Metal Centers Exhibiting High Gas Adsorption Affinity
      Ma, Shengqian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (36), 11734-11735CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A metal-org. framework, H2[Co4O(TATB)8/3] (PCN-9, H3TATB = 4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoic acid), contg. entatic metal centers, was synthesized and crystallog. characterized, and its gas adsorption was studied. The H2 and CH4 adsorption enthalpies of PCN-9 are among the highest reported thus far.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XosVChs7g%253D&md5=6263507a8d922d1e954f3282681c2275

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3c
      Bridging-ligand-substitution strategy for the preparation of metal-organic polyhedra
      Li, Jian-Rong; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Nature Chemistry (2010), 2 (10), 893-898CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Metal-org. polyhedra-discrete mol. architectures constructed through the coordination of metal ions and org. linkers-have recently attracted considerable attention due to their intriguing structures, their potential for a variety of applications and their relevance to biol. self-assembly. Several synthetic routes were studied to prep. these complexes. However, to date, these preparative methods have typically been based on the direct assembly of metal ions and org. linkers. Although these routes are convenient, it remains difficult to find suitable reaction conditions or to control the outcome of the assembly process. Here, the authors demonstrate a synthetic strategy based on the substitution of org. dicarboxylic acid bridging ligands (H2L) in sol. copper metal-org. polyhedra; eg. Cu24(L)24(S)24 where S = solvent. The introduction of linkers with different properties from those of the initial metal-org. polyhedra can thus lead to new metal-org. polyhedra with distinct properties (including size and shape). Also, partial substitution can also occur and form mixed-ligand species that may be difficult to access by other approaches.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtF2ms7fM&md5=8188ae4e3052f0a94b92ead42456207e
      (d) Yan, Y.; Telepeni, I.; Yang, S.-H.; Lin, X.; Kockelmann, W.; Dailly, A.; Blake, A. J.; Lewis, W.; Walker, G. S.; Allan, D. R.; Barnett, S. A.; Champness, N. R.; Schröder, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 4092 DOI: 10.1021/ja1001407
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3d
      Metal-Organic Polyhedral Frameworks: High H2 Adsorption Capacities and Neutron Powder Diffraction Studies
      Yan, Yong; Telepeni, Irvin; Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Kockelmann, Winfried; Dailly, Anne; Blake, Alexander J.; Lewis, William; Walker, Gavin S.; Allan, David R.; Barnett, Sarah A.; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (12), 4092-4094CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The metal-org. polyhedral framework complex [Cu3(L)(H2O)3]·16DMF·26H2O (NOTT-112, H6L = 1,3,5-tris(4-(3,5-dicarboxyphenylethynyl)phenyl)benzene) was prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. and hydrogen adsorption expts. Neutron powder diffraction expts. on D2-loaded NOTT-112 reveal that the axial sites of exposed Cu(II) ions in the smallest cuboctahedral cages are the 1st, strongest binding sites for D2 leading to an overall discrimination between the two types of exposed Cu(II) sites at the paddlewheel nodes. Thus, the Cu(II) centers within the cuboctahedral cage are the 1st sites of D2 binding with a Cu-D2 distance of 2.23(1) Å.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      3e
      Highly porous metal-organic framework sustained with 12-connected nanoscopic octahedra
      Lu, Weigang; Yuan, Daqiang; Makal, Trevor A.; Wei, Zhangwen; Li, Jian-Rong; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Dalton Transactions (2013), 42 (5), 1708-1714CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two dicopper(II)-paddlewheel-based metal-org. frameworks (PCN-81 and -82) were synthesized by using tetratopic ligands featuring 90°-carbazole-dicarboxylate moieties. Both adopt 12-connected tfb topol. with nanoscopic octahedra as building units. The freeze-dried PCN-82 shows Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas as high as 4488 and 4859 m2 g-1, resp. It also exhibits high H2-adsorption capacity at low pressure (300 cm3 g-1 or 2.6% at 77 K and 1 bar), which can be attributed to its high surface area, microporosity, and open metal sites.

      3f
      Multifunctional metal-organic frameworks constructed from meta-benzenedicarboxylate units
      He, Yabing; Li, Bin; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin
      Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5618-5656CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also known as porous coordination polymers (PCPs), are an emerging type of porous materials which are formed by the self-assembly of metallic centers and bridging org. linkers. Design and synthesis of org. linkers are very crit. to target MOFs with desired structures and properties. In this review, we summarize and highlight the recent development of porous MOFs that are constructed from the multicarboxylate ligands contg. m-benzenedicarboxylate moieties, and their promising applications in gas storage and sepn., heterogeneous catalysis and luminescent sensing.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

The activated 1 displays type-I N2 gas sorption behavior with a Langmuir surface area of 607 m2 g-1 and exhibits interesting selective gas adsorption for C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4.

      8
      Tetradecanuclear polycarbonatolanthanoid clusters: Diverse coordination modes of carbonate providing access to novel core geometries
      Chesman, Anthony S. R.; Turner, David R.; Moubaraki, Boujemaa; Murray, Keith S.; Deacon, Glen B.; Batten, Stuart R.
      Dalton Transactions (2012), 41 (36), 10903-10909CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The synthesis of two high nuclearity lanthanoid clusters demonstrates the versatility of the carbonate anion as a robust cluster forming agent, potentially allowing for the formation of otherwise inaccessible core topologies. The complexes, [Gd14(CO3)13(ccnm)9(OH)(H2O)6(phen)13(NO3)](CO3)2.5·(phen)0.5 (1) and [Dy14(CO3)13(ccnm)10(OH)(H2O)6(phen)13](CO3)2.5·(phen)0.5 (2) (ccnm = carbamoylcyanonitrosomethanide, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), contain a [Ln14(CO3)13(OH)] core in which the carbonate anions display four unique coordination modes. The complexes are chiral, and the ccnm ligands also display four unique coordination modes. Extensive intra- and intermol. π-π stacking between phen ligands gives 1-dimensional chains in the crystal structure. Both complexes display magnetic properties that are indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling, with complex 2 displaying behavior consistent with possible single mol. magnet properties.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      9a
      Structural Diversity of Infinite 3d-4f Heterometallic Cluster Compounds Driven by Various Lanthanide Radii
      Xiang, Shengchang; Hu, Shengmin; Sheng, Tianlu; Chen, Jianshan; Wu, Xintao
      Chemistry--A European Journal (2009), 15 (45), 12496-12502, S12496/1-S12496/16CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The syntheses, structures, and characterization of six Ln3+-Cu2+-glycine (Hgly) coordination polymers were described. They represent three types of structures: (Ln = La (1), Pr (2), and Sm (3)) is a 1-dimensional catenarian polymer comprising [Ln2] nodes bridged by four cis-Cu(gly)2 linkers. [Ln2(H2O)6(L1)2(L2)2].6ClO4.4H2O [Ln = La(1), Pr (2), and Sm (3)] for type I; Na2[Eu6Cu22(OH)28(Hgly)4(gly)12(ClO4)(H2O)18](L3)3.23ClO4.28H2O (4) and [Dy6Cu22(OH)28(Hgly)4(gly)12(ClO4)(H2O)18](L3)3.21ClO4.2OH2O (5) for type II; and Na4[Er6Cu24(Hgly)2(gly)12(OH)30(ClO4)(H2O)22](L3)6.27ClO4.36H2O (6) for type III; in all of which L1, L2, and L3 are the cis-[Cu(gly)2], cis-[Cu(gly)2(H2O)], and trans-[Cu(gly)2], resp. Type II (Ln = Eu (4) and Dy (5)) is a 2-dimensional open framework with a 44-net, composed of novel [Ln6Cu22] cluster nodes linked by trans-Cu(gly)2 linkers. Also, the inner structures of the [Ln6Cu22] nodes, and the connection mode between the nodes and linkers are slightly different for 4 and 5. Type III (Ln = Er (6)) is a 3-dimensional open framework with a novel 36·418·53·6 topol., made up of [Er6Cu24] cluster nodes and trans-Cu(gly)2 linkers. The rich variety of the resulting structures owes itself mainly to the interselection between the dynamic control of metalloligands and cationic components. A transition from frequency dependence to frequency independence is obsd. in the field-induced magnetization lag for 1-3. The frequency dependence at low temps. may come from the antiferromagnetic Cu-Cu interaction through the [Ln2] nodes, whereas the frequency independence may be due to the disappearance of the antiferromagnetic Cu-Cu interaction at high temps.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Controllable assembly, structures, and properties of lanthanide-transition metal-amino acid clusters
      Xiang, Sheng-Chang; Hu, Sheng-Min; Sheng, Tian-Lu; Chen, Ling; Wu, Xin-Tao
      Structure and Bonding (Berlin, Germany) (2009), 133 (Controlled Assembly and Modification of Inorganic Systems), 161-206CODEN: STBGAG; ISSN:0081-5993. (Springer GmbH)
      A review. Amino acids are the basic building blocks in the chem. of life. This chapter describes the controllable assembly, structures and properties of lathanide(III)-transition metal-amino acid clusters developed recently by our group. The effects on the assembly of several factors of influence, such as presence of a secondary ligand, lanthanides, crystn. conditions, the ratio of metal ions to amino acids, and transition metal ions have been expounded. The dynamic balance of metalloligands and the substitution of weak coordination bonds account for the occurrence of diverse structures in this series of compds.

      A 12-connected metal-organic framework constructed from an unprecedented cyclic dodecanuclear copper cluster
      Zhang, Huan; Lu, Ying; Zhang, Zhiming; Fu, Hai; Li, Yangguang; Volkmer, Dirk; Denysenko, Dmytro; Wang, Enbo
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (58), 7295-7297CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2 with Hpz and H3BTC in H2O-MeOH solvent at 150 ° for 72 h afforded blue octahedral-shaped crystals formulated as H2Na4[Cu12(OH)6(pz)6(BTC)6]·23H2O (1, pz = pyrazolate, BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate). Compd. 1 is 12-connected metal-org. framework based on an unprecedented cyclic Cu12 cluster with a 10.115 Å diam. internal cavity. Compd. 1 undergoes nearly complete exchange of sodium cation with lithium, potassium, cesium, manganese(II), and nickel(II).

      12a
      A 3D Canted Antiferromagnetic Porous Metal-Organic Framework with Anatase Topology through Assembly of an Analogue of Polyoxometalate
      Xiang, Shengchang; Wu, Xintao; Zhang, Jianjun; Fu, Ruibiao; Hu, Shengmin; Zhang, Xudong
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (47), 16352-16353CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The unique porous metal-org. framework {KCo3(C6H4O7)(C6H5O7)(H2O)2·8H2O}8 (1), which exhibits an unprecedented infinite 3-dimensional (3,6)-connected decorated anatase net, was obtained by hydrothermal reaction. Upon dehydration, the compd. retains crystallinity and exhibits a type I N2 sorption isotherm, characteristic of a microporous solid with apparent Langmuir surface area 939 m2/g and pore vol. 0.31 cm3/g. Magnetic measurements for both 1 and dehydrated 1 show the spin-canted antiferromagnetic state <5 K and a magnetic hysteresis loop at 2 K. Thus, dehydrated 1 represents the 1st metal-org. framework for which microporosity and a spin-canted antiferromagnetic state coexist, which demonstrates that the self-assembly of organo-polymetal clusters and metal ions can provide a potential route to magnetic porous metal-org. frameworks.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFKrt7zL&md5=c386931b983ad804d6bdc98a3c75dbf8

      12b
      Highly-connected, porous coordination polymers based on [M4(μ3-OH)2] (M = CoII and NiII) clusters: different networks, adsorption and magnetic properties
      Chen, Qing; Xue, Wei; Lin, Jian-Bin; Lin, Rui-Biao; Zeng, Ming-Hua; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Dalton Transactions (2012), 41 (14), 4199-4206CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two new 3-dimensional coordination polymers based on tetranuclear clusters, {[Co4(ina)5(μ3-OH)2(H2O)(EtOH)]NO3·2EtOH·4H2O}n (1) (Hina = isonicotinic acid) and {[Ni4(ina)5(μ3-OH)2(EtCOO)]·6EtOH·2H2O}n (2), were obtained by the solvothermal reactions from Hina and different metal salts. The [M4(μ3-OH)2] cores act as 7- and 9-connected nodes and are extended through ina linkers to highly-connected frameworks with vmr net for 1 and bct-9-P21/c net for 2. Both the desolvated frameworks display effective gas sorption capacities of N2 and H2 with Langmuir surface areas of 546 and 917 m2 g-1 for 1 and 2, resp. Magnetic studies show spin canting and spin-glass behaviors with Tg = 6.0 and 15.0 K for 1 and 2, resp. The intra- and inter-tetramer coupling interactions and cooperative magnetic correlation greatly influence the bulk magnetic behaviors in this system.

      Six new coordination polymers based on a tritopic pyridyldicarboxylate ligand: structural, magnetic and sorption properties
      Ding, Tao; Ren, Li-Di; Du, Xiao-Di; Quan, Li; Gao, Zi-Wei; Zhang, Wei-Qiang; Zheng, Chang-Zheng
      CrystEngComm (2014), 16 (33), 7790-7801CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Using a rigid ligand, pyridine-3,5-bis(phenyl-4-carboxylic) acid (H2L), six new coordination polymers were synthesized under solvothermal conditions, formulated as [Co(L)(DMF)] (1), [Co(L)(H2O)]·DMF (2), [Co3(L)2(HCOO)2(H2O)2] (3), [Co5(L)4(OH)2(H2O)2]·0.5DMF·H2O (4), [Mn(L)(H2O)]·DMF (5), and [Zn(L)]·DMF (6). Complex 1 exhibits a 2-dimensional layer structure with a four-connected net. 2 Is also a 2-dimensional layer net which forms a 2-dimensional stacked layers porous framework through H bonding interactions. In 3, 10-connected clusters [Co3(COO)6] are extended by a L2- linker to construct a 3-dimensional (3,10)-connected framework with a (4·6·8)(42·62·810·10) topol. net. As for 4, a rare pentanuclear cluster, [Co5(μ3-OH)2(COO)8N4], serves as a 12-connected node to give a 3-dimensional (3,12)-connected framework with a larger solvent accessible vol. 5 Shows a 2-dimensional 44 layer framework by considering Mn(II) as a four-connected node. 6 Exhibits a 3-dimensional framework based on 1-dimensional Zn-(COO)-Zn chains. All complexes were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, elemental anal., TGA and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. The magnetic properties of complexes 1-5 and the photoluminescence properties for 6 were studied. H2, N2 and CO2 adsorption measurements were carried out for 4.

      14a
      Antiferromagnetic Porous Metal-Organic Framework Containing Mixed-Valence [MnII4MnIII2(μ4-O)2]10+ Units with Catecholase Activity and Selective Gas Adsorption
      Kar, Paramita; Haldar, Ritesh; Gomez-Garcia, Carlos J.; Ghosh, Ashutosh
      Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (7), 4265-4273CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A multifunctional porous metal org. framework based on mixed-valence hexa-nuclear [MnIII2MnII4O2(pyz)2(C6H5CH2COO)10] (pyz = pyrazine) units has been synthesized. The complex has been characterized by elemental anal., IR spectroscopy, single-crystal x-ray diffraction anal., and variable-temp. magnetic measurements. The structural anal. reveals that the bidentate pyz mols. connect each [Mn6] unit to its four [Mn6] neighbors through the peripheral Mn(II) centers, giving rise to a three-dimensional (3D) distorted diamond-like porous framework. Variable-temp. (2-300 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements show dominant antiferromagnetic interactions within the discrete [Mn6] cluster that have been fitted with a model contg. three exchange consts. developed for the complex (J1 = -8.6 cm-1, J2 = -3.9 cm-1, and J3 = -100.0 cm-1). Using 3,5-di-tert-Bu catechol (3,5-DTBC) as the substrate, catecholase activity of the complex has been studied; the turn over no. is of 2547 h-1 in acetonitrile. This porous compd. shows remarkable selectivity for adsorption of CO2 over N2 that may be correlated with the effect of window flexibility of the pore to the corresponding adsorbate mols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Construction of Two Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks with flu and pyr Topologies Based on Zn4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6 and Zn6(μ6-O)(CO2)6 Secondary Building Units
      Li, Xing-Jun; Jiang, Fei-Long; Wu, Ming-Yan; Chen, Lian; Qian, Jin-Jie; Zhou, Kang; Yuan, Da-Qiang; Hong, Mao-Chun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (2), 1032-1038CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      By employment of a tripodal phosphoric carboxylate ligand, tris-(4-carboxylphenyl)-phosphine oxide (H3TPO), two novel porous metal-org. frameworks, namely, [Zn2(μ3-OH)(TPO)(H2O)] (1) and [Zn6(μ6-O)-(TPO)2](NO3)4·3H2O (2), were synthesized by solvothermal methods. Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit three-dimensional microporous frameworks with flu and pyr topologies and possess rare butterfly-shaped Zn4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6 and octahedral Zn6(μ6-O)-(CO2)6 secondary building units, resp. Large cavities and 1-dimensional channels are obsd. in these two frameworks. Gas-sorption measurements indicate that complex 2 has a good H2 uptake capacity of 171.9 cm3 g-1 (1.53%) at 77 K and 1.08 bar, and its ideal adsorbed soln. theory calcn. predicts highly selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4. Also, complexes 1 and 2 exhibit excellent blue emission at room temp.

      Four Coordination Polymers Based on Identical Eight-Connected Heptanuclear Clusters: Spin Canting, Spin Glass, Antiferromagnetism, and Gas Adsorption
      Li, Jia; Li, Bao; Huang, Peng; Shi, Hai-Yan; Huang, Rong-Bin; Zheng, Lan-Sun; Tao, Jun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (19), 11573-11579CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Four 3-dimensional coordination polymers, [Co7(OH)4(H2O)2(ina)4(IP)3]·10H2O (1·10H2O, ina = isonicotinate, IP = isophthalate), [Ni7(OH)4(H2O)2(ina)4(IP)3]·10H2O (2·10H2O), [Co7(OH)4(H2O)2(ina)4(pip)3]·5H2O (3·5H2O, pip = 5-phenylisophthalate), and [Ni7(OH)4(H2O)2(ina)4(pip)3]·5H2O (4·5H2O), were hydrothermally synthesized. They crystd. in the orthorhombic space group Pba2 for 1·10H2O and 2·10H2O and monoclinic space group P2/n for 3·5H2O and 4·5H2O, and were constructed with the identical 8-connected heptanuclear {M7(OH)4} (M = CoII or NiII) clusters, possessing uninodal hexagonal primitive net with the point symbol {36·418·53·6}. The four coordination polymers showed dominant antiferromagnetic properties in which 1·10H2O shows spin-canted behavior and 2·10H2O exhibits the coexistence of spin canting and spin glass. Meanwhile, the activated polymers 1 and 2 possessed permanent porosity, displaying relatively large H2 uptake capacity (77 K, 1 atm) of 114 and 133 cm3 g-1, and CO2 uptake capacity (273 K, 1 atm) of 65.8 and 73.3 cm3 g-1, for 1 and 2, resp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A Porous Metal-Organic Framework Constructed from Carboxylate-Pyrazolate Shared Heptanuclear Zinc Clusters: Synthesis, Gas Adsorption, and Guest-Dependent Luminescent Properties
      Zheng, Qingshu; Yang, Feilong; Deng, Mingli; Ling, Yun; Liu, Xiaofeng; Chen, Zhenxia; Wang, Yunhua; Weng, Linhong; Zhou, Yaming
      Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (18), 10368-10374CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A three-dimensional porous structure of [Zn7O2(bpdc)4(dmpp)2]·6DEF·10H2O (MAC-7, H2bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, Hdmpp = 3,5-dimethyl-4-(4'-pyridyl)-pyrazole), built of 12-bridged carboxylate-pyrazolate shared Zn7O2 clusters, was synthesized. Because of the presence of 12-bridged carboxylate-pyrazolate shared building block, MAC-7 is a double-linked pcu-type framework and shows reversible phase transformation. Photoluminescent property studies indicate that MAC-7 could sense nitrobenzene over toluene, p-xylene, and mesitylene by luminescent quenching.

      Cubic Octanuclear Ni(II) Clusters in Highly Porous Polypyrazolyl-Based Materials
      Masciocchi, Norberto; Galli, Simona; Colombo, Valentina; Maspero, Angelo; Palmisano, Giovanni; Seyyedi, Behnam; Lamberti, Carlo; Bordiga, Silvia
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (23), 7902-7904CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Two highly porous coordination polymers [Ni8(OH)4(H2O)2(pbp)6] (H2pbp = 4,4'-bis(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)biphenyl) and [Ni8(OH)4(H2O)2(tet)6] (H2tet = 2,6-bis(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)pyrrolo(3,4-J)isoindole-1.3.5.7(2H,6H)-tetrone), contg. rare octanuclear hydroxo-nickel clusters and long bis-pyrazolyl spacers were prepd. and shown to possess, after mild thermal treatment, lattice cavities up to 72% of the total crystal vol. They were characterized by XRD, UV-visible, NIR, XANES, EXAFS and thermodiffractometric studies.

      (a) Sheldrick, G. M. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Found. Crystallogr. 2008, 64, 112 DOI: 10.1107/S0108767307043930

      17a
      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
      (b) Dolomanov, A. V.; Bourhis, L. J.; Gildea, R. J.; Howard, J. A. K.; Puschmann, H. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2009, 42, 339 DOI: 10.1107/S0021889808042726
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17b
      OLEX2: a complete structure solution, refinement and analysis program
      Dolomanov, Oleg V.; Bourhis, Luc J.; Gildea, Richard J.; Howard, Judith A. K.; Puschmann, Horst
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2009), 42 (2), 339-341CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (International Union of Crystallography)
      New software, OLEX2, was developed for the detn., visualization and anal. of mol. crystal structures. The software has a portable mouse-driven workflow-oriented and fully comprehensive graphical user interface for structure soln., refinement and report generation, as well as novel tools for structure anal. OLEX2 seamlessly links all aspects of the structure soln., refinement and publication process and presents them in a single workflow-driven package, with the ultimate goal of producing an application which will be useful to both chemists and crystallographers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
      Spek, A. L.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
      The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

      21
      Adsorption of Gases and Vapors on Carbon Molecular Sieves
      O'koye, I. P.; Benham, M.; Thomas, K. M.
      Langmuir (1997), 13 (15), 4054-4059CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      The adsorption phenomena of oxygen and nitrogen on a carbon mol. sieve were studied above the crit. temp. of the adsorptives as a function of pressure in order to understand further the mechanism of air sepn. The uptake of both gases studied was virtually linear at low equil. pressures, in agreement with Henry's law, but deviation occurred at higher pressures. The adsorption kinetics were studied with different amts. of preadsorbed gas for changes in pressure of 11 kPa and partial pressure in helium of ∼10 kPa. The gas adsorption kinetics obey a linear driving force mass transfer model. The ratios of the rate consts. (kO2/kN2) for each pressure increment were 35-43 for pure gases and 21-27 for gas/helium mixts., and these ratios clearly demonstrate the mol. sieving characteristics. The presence of water vapor is detrimental to the operation of carbon mol. sieves. The adsorption and desorption characteristics of water vapor with different amts. of preadsorbed water were studied for comparison with oxygen and nitrogen adsorption over the pressure range 0-1.8 kPa for pressure steps of 0.1 kPa. The results are discussed in terms of the mechanism of gas sepn. using carbon mol. sieves.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXkt1Ghtrs%253D&md5=86b09c68b0b669689c4d4d9471e16103

      (a) Xiang, S.-C.; Zhang, Z.-J.; Zhao, C.-G.; Hong, K.; Zhao, X.; Ding, D.-R.; Xie, M.-H.; Wu, C.-D.; Das, M. C.; Gill, R.; Thomas, K. M.; Chen, B.-L. Nat. Commun. 2011, 2, 204 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms1206
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22a
      Rationally tuned micropores within enantiopure metal-organic frameworks for highly selective separation of acetylene and ethylene
      Xiang Sheng-Chang; Zhang Zhangjing; Zhao Cong-Gui; Hong Kunlun; Zhao Xuebo; Ding De-Rong; Xie Ming-Hua; Wu Chuan-De; Das Madhab C; Gill Rachel; Thomas K Mark; Chen Banglin
      Nature communications (2011), 2 (), 204 ISSN:.
      Separation of acetylene and ethylene is an important industrial process because both compounds are essential reagents for a range of chemical products and materials. Current separation approaches include the partial hydrogenation of acetylene into ethylene over a supported Pd catalyst, and the extraction of cracked olefins using an organic solvent; both routes are costly and energy consuming. Adsorption technologies may allow separation, but microporous materials exhibiting highly selective adsorption of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4) have not been realized to date. Here, we report the development of tunable microporous enantiopure mixed-metal-organic framework (M'MOF) materials for highly selective separation of C(2)H(2) and C(2)H(4). The high selectivities achieved suggest the potential application of microporous M'MOFs for practical adsorption-based separation of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M3htlSrtg%253D%253D&md5=1fb20400fe51c39c12dee76feb72858e
      (b) Xiang, S.-C.; Zhou, W.; Zhang, Z.-J.; Green, M. A.; Liu, Y.; Chen, B.-L. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2010, 49, 4615 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201000094
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Open Metal Sites within Isostructural Metal-Organic Frameworks for Differential Recognition of Acetylene and Extraordinarily High Acetylene Storage Capacity at Room Temperature
      Xiang, Shengchang; Zhou, Wei; Zhang, Zhangjing; Green, Mark A.; Liu, Yun; Chen, Banglin
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (27), 4615-4618, S4615/1-S4615/17CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A series of isostructural metal-org. frameworks with open metal sites were examd. for their differential recognition of acetylene mols. The open metal sites within them exhibit the interaction in which cobalt ion has the strongest interaction with acetylene and a high adsorption enthalpy. This high capacity maximizes the safe acetylene storage d. in bulk materials.

      Krishna, R.; Smit, B.; Calero, S. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2002, 31, 185 DOI: 10.1039/b101267n
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      Entropy effects during sorption of alkanes in zeolites
      Krishna, Rajamani; Smit, Berend; Calero, Sofia
      Chemical Society Reviews (2002), 31 (3), 185-194CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Recent developments in Configurational-Bias Monte Carlo (CBMC) techniques allow the accurate calcn. of the sorption isotherms for alkanes, and their mixts., in various zeolites. The CBMC simulations give new insights into subtle entropy effects affecting mixt. adsorption. Three types of entropy effects can be distinguished. (1) Size entropy effects favor the component with the smaller no. of C atoms because the smaller mol. finds it easier to fill in the 'gaps' within the zeolite matrix at high mol. loadings. (2) Configurational entropy effects come into play for mixts. of alkanes that differ in the degree of branching. For a mixt. of linear and branched alkanes with the same no. of C atoms, configurational entropy effects favor the linear isomer because such mols. 'pack' more efficiently within, say, the intersecting channel topol. of MFI zeolite. (3) Length entropy effects comes into force for sorption of linear and branched alkanes within the cylindrical channels of say AFI and MOR zeolites; here the double branched alkane has the shortest length and can be packed more efficiently within the channels. We demonstrate that CBMC simulations allow the efficient screening of zeolite structures for a given sepn. duty and aid the development of novel sepn. processes exploiting entropy effects.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xjtlyls74%253D&md5=748670d769d7f9aaeb79d8e331c42de5
    24. 24
      McDonald, T. M.; D’Alessandro, D. M.; Krishnac, R.; Long, J. R. Chem. Sci. 2011, 2, 2022 DOI: 10.1039/c1sc00354b
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Enhanced carbon dioxide capture upon incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine in the metal-organic framework CuBTTri
      McDonald, Thomas M.; D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Krishna, Rajamani; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Chemical Science (2011), 2 (10), 2022-2028CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      High capacity, high selectivity, and low-cost regeneration conditions are the most important criteria by which new adsorbents for post-combustion CO2 capture will be judged. The incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine (mmen) into H3(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8 (CuBTTri; H3BTTri = 1,3,5-tri(1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)benzene), a H2O-stable, triazolate-bridged framework, is shown to drastically enhance CO2 adsorption, resulting in one of the best performing metal-org. frameworks for CO2 sepn. reported to date. High porosity was maintained despite stoichiometric attachment of mmen to the open metal sites of the framework, resulting in a BET surface area of 870 m2 g-1. At 25° under a 0.15 bar CO2/0.75 bar N2 mixt., mmen-CuBTTri adsorbs 2.38 mmol CO2 g-1 (9.5%) with a selectivity of 327, as detd. using Ideal Adsorbed Soln. Theory (IAST). The high capacity and selectivity are consequences of the exceptionally large isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption, calcd. to be -96 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage. IR spectra support chemisorption between amines and CO2 as one of the primary mechanisms of uptake. Despite the large initial heat of adsorption, the CO2 uptake was fully reversible and the framework could be easily regenerated at 60°, enabling a cycling time of just 27 min with no loss of capacity over 72 adsorption/desorption cycles.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Structural Diversity of Infinite 3d-4f Heterometallic Cluster Compounds Driven by Various Lanthanide Radii
      Xiang, Shengchang; Hu, Shengmin; Sheng, Tianlu; Chen, Jianshan; Wu, Xintao
      Chemistry--A European Journal (2009), 15 (45), 12496-12502, S12496/1-S12496/16CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The syntheses, structures, and characterization of six Ln3+-Cu2+-glycine (Hgly) coordination polymers were described. They represent three types of structures: (Ln = La (1), Pr (2), and Sm (3)) is a 1-dimensional catenarian polymer comprising [Ln2] nodes bridged by four cis-Cu(gly)2 linkers. [Ln2(H2O)6(L1)2(L2)2].6ClO4.4H2O [Ln = La(1), Pr (2), and Sm (3)] for type I; Na2[Eu6Cu22(OH)28(Hgly)4(gly)12(ClO4)(H2O)18](L3)3.23ClO4.28H2O (4) and [Dy6Cu22(OH)28(Hgly)4(gly)12(ClO4)(H2O)18](L3)3.21ClO4.2OH2O (5) for type II; and Na4[Er6Cu24(Hgly)2(gly)12(OH)30(ClO4)(H2O)22](L3)6.27ClO4.36H2O (6) for type III; in all of which L1, L2, and L3 are the cis-[Cu(gly)2], cis-[Cu(gly)2(H2O)], and trans-[Cu(gly)2], resp. Type II (Ln = Eu (4) and Dy (5)) is a 2-dimensional open framework with a 44-net, composed of novel [Ln6Cu22] cluster nodes linked by trans-Cu(gly)2 linkers. Also, the inner structures of the [Ln6Cu22] nodes, and the connection mode between the nodes and linkers are slightly different for 4 and 5. Type III (Ln = Er (6)) is a 3-dimensional open framework with a novel 36·418·53·6 topol., made up of [Er6Cu24] cluster nodes and trans-Cu(gly)2 linkers. The rich variety of the resulting structures owes itself mainly to the interselection between the dynamic control of metalloligands and cationic components. A transition from frequency dependence to frequency independence is obsd. in the field-induced magnetization lag for 1-3. The frequency dependence at low temps. may come from the antiferromagnetic Cu-Cu interaction through the [Ln2] nodes, whereas the frequency independence may be due to the disappearance of the antiferromagnetic Cu-Cu interaction at high temps.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      25b
      Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Physical Properties of Two Noninterpenetrated Pillar-Layered Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on N,N'-Di(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide Pillar
      Han, Lei; Xu, Lan-Ping; Qin, Lan; Zhao, Wen-Na; Yan, Xiao-Zhi; Yu, Lei
      Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (10), 4260-4267CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Two 3-dimensional noninterpenetrated pillar-layered metal-org. frameworks were synthesized under solvothermal reactions based on a N,N'-di-(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide (DPNDI) pillar. Single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compd. [Co3(BDC)3(DPNDI)-(DMF)2]·2CH3CN (1) displays an eight-connected hex net with Schlaefli symbol 36·418·53·6 and consists of a DPNDI pillar and 2-dimensional 36 net layer that was constructed from a pinwheel trimetallic secondary building unit and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) linker. [Zn2(HFIPBB)2(DPNDI)]·8DMF (2) exhibits a six-connected mab net with Schlaefli symbol 44·610·8 and consists of a DPNDI pillar and 2-dimensional wavelike 44 net layer with helical channels that was constructed from a paddlewheel dimetallic secondary building unit and bent V-type 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoate) linker. The phase purity, thermal stability, and N2 adsorption/desorption of 1 and 2 were measured; the antiferromagnetic property of 1 as well as the photochromic phenomenon of 2 also were studied and discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      25c
      Solvent controlled assembly of four Mn(II)-2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate frameworks with rod-packing architectures and magnetic properties
      Tan, Yan-Xi; He, Yan-Ping; Zhang, Ying; Zheng, Yan-Jun; Zhang, Jian
      CrystEngComm (2013), 15 (30), 6009-6014CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      To study the role of solvents on the self-assembly of coordination frameworks, the reactions between MnCl2·4H2O and thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylate (thb) ligand in different solvents at 120° produced four new Mn-thb complexes. These Mn-thb frameworks, [Mn2(thb)2(pyro)3] (1, pyro = 2-pyrrolidinone), [Mn3(thb)3(pyro)3] (2), [Mn2(thb)2(DMA)2] (3, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), and [Mn2(thb)2(MeCO2)]·H2NMe2 (4), all use a rod-and-spacer assembly mode, but their rod-packing architectures are totally different because of the structure-directing effect of solvents. The topologies of 1, 2, 3 and 4 are novel (3,5)-connected net, hex, irl and sra, resp. Solvents with different conformations play a significant role in promoting the diversity of structures. The magnetic properties of 1, 2 and 3 also were studied.
