        Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 7 DOI: 10.1107/S0021889802022112
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Adsorption of Gases and Vapors on Carbon Molecular Sieves
        O'koye, I. P.; Benham, M.; Thomas, K. M.
        Langmuir (1997), 13 (15), 4054-4059CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
        The adsorption phenomena of oxygen and nitrogen on a carbon mol. sieve were studied above the crit. temp. of the adsorptives as a function of pressure in order to understand further the mechanism of air sepn. The uptake of both gases studied was virtually linear at low equil. pressures, in agreement with Henry's law, but deviation occurred at higher pressures. The adsorption kinetics were studied with different amts. of preadsorbed gas for changes in pressure of 11 kPa and partial pressure in helium of ∼10 kPa. The gas adsorption kinetics obey a linear driving force mass transfer model. The ratios of the rate consts. (kO2/kN2) for each pressure increment were 35-43 for pure gases and 21-27 for gas/helium mixts., and these ratios clearly demonstrate the mol. sieving characteristics. The presence of water vapor is detrimental to the operation of carbon mol. sieves. The adsorption and desorption characteristics of water vapor with different amts. of preadsorbed water were studied for comparison with oxygen and nitrogen adsorption over the pressure range 0-1.8 kPa for pressure steps of 0.1 kPa. The results are discussed in terms of the mechanism of gas sepn. using carbon mol. sieves.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXkt1Ghtrs%253D&md5=86b09c68b0b669689c4d4d9471e16103

        (a) Xiang, S.-C.; Zhang, Z.-J.; Zhao, C.-G.; Hong, K.; Zhao, X.; Ding, D.-R.; Xie, M.-H.; Wu, C.-D.; Das, M. C.; Gill, R.; Thomas, K. M.; Chen, B.-L. Nat. Commun. 2011, 2, 204 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms1206
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22a
        Rationally tuned micropores within enantiopure metal-organic frameworks for highly selective separation of acetylene and ethylene
        Xiang Sheng-Chang; Zhang Zhangjing; Zhao Cong-Gui; Hong Kunlun; Zhao Xuebo; Ding De-Rong; Xie Ming-Hua; Wu Chuan-De; Das Madhab C; Gill Rachel; Thomas K Mark; Chen Banglin
        Nature communications (2011), 2 (), 204 ISSN:.
        Separation of acetylene and ethylene is an important industrial process because both compounds are essential reagents for a range of chemical products and materials. Current separation approaches include the partial hydrogenation of acetylene into ethylene over a supported Pd catalyst, and the extraction of cracked olefins using an organic solvent; both routes are costly and energy consuming. Adsorption technologies may allow separation, but microporous materials exhibiting highly selective adsorption of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4) have not been realized to date. Here, we report the development of tunable microporous enantiopure mixed-metal-organic framework (M'MOF) materials for highly selective separation of C(2)H(2) and C(2)H(4). The high selectivities achieved suggest the potential application of microporous M'MOFs for practical adsorption-based separation of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M3htlSrtg%253D%253D&md5=1fb20400fe51c39c12dee76feb72858e

        Open Metal Sites within Isostructural Metal-Organic Frameworks for Differential Recognition of Acetylene and Extraordinarily High Acetylene Storage Capacity at Room Temperature

        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (27), 4615-4618, S4615/1-S4615/17CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A series of isostructural metal-org. frameworks with open metal sites were examd. for their differential recognition of acetylene mols. The open metal sites within them exhibit the interaction in which cobalt ion has the strongest interaction with acetylene and a high adsorption enthalpy. This high capacity maximizes the safe acetylene storage d. in bulk materials.

        Krishna, R.; Smit, B.; Calero, S. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2002, 31, 185 DOI: 10.1039/b101267n
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        Entropy effects during sorption of alkanes in zeolites
        Krishna, Rajamani; Smit, Berend; Calero, Sofia
        Chemical Society Reviews (2002), 31 (3), 185-194CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Recent developments in Configurational-Bias Monte Carlo (CBMC) techniques allow the accurate calcn. of the sorption isotherms for alkanes, and their mixts., in various zeolites. The CBMC simulations give new insights into subtle entropy effects affecting mixt. adsorption. Three types of entropy effects can be distinguished. (1) Size entropy effects favor the component with the smaller no. of C atoms because the smaller mol. finds it easier to fill in the 'gaps' within the zeolite matrix at high mol. loadings. (2) Configurational entropy effects come into play for mixts. of alkanes that differ in the degree of branching. For a mixt. of linear and branched alkanes with the same no. of C atoms, configurational entropy effects favor the linear isomer because such mols. 'pack' more efficiently within, say, the intersecting channel topol. of MFI zeolite. (3) Length entropy effects comes into force for sorption of linear and branched alkanes within the cylindrical channels of say AFI and MOR zeolites; here the double branched alkane has the shortest length and can be packed more efficiently within the channels. We demonstrate that CBMC simulations allow the efficient screening of zeolite structures for a given sepn. duty and aid the development of novel sepn. processes exploiting entropy effects.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xjtlyls74%253D&md5=748670d769d7f9aaeb79d8e331c42de5
      24. 24
        McDonald, T. M.; D’Alessandro, D. M.; Krishnac, R.; Long, J. R. Chem. Sci. 2011, 2, 2022 DOI: 10.1039/c1sc00354b
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Enhanced carbon dioxide capture upon incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine in the metal-organic framework CuBTTri
        McDonald, Thomas M.; D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Krishna, Rajamani; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemical Science (2011), 2 (10), 2022-2028CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        High capacity, high selectivity, and low-cost regeneration conditions are the most important criteria by which new adsorbents for post-combustion CO2 capture will be judged. The incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine (mmen) into H3(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8 (CuBTTri; H3BTTri = 1,3,5-tri(1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)benzene), a H2O-stable, triazolate-bridged framework, is shown to drastically enhance CO2 adsorption, resulting in one of the best performing metal-org. frameworks for CO2 sepn. reported to date. High porosity was maintained despite stoichiometric attachment of mmen to the open metal sites of the framework, resulting in a BET surface area of 870 m2 g-1. At 25° under a 0.15 bar CO2/0.75 bar N2 mixt., mmen-CuBTTri adsorbs 2.38 mmol CO2 g-1 (9.5%) with a selectivity of 327, as detd. using Ideal Adsorbed Soln. Theory (IAST). The high capacity and selectivity are consequences of the exceptionally large isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption, calcd. to be -96 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage. IR spectra support chemisorption between amines and CO2 as one of the primary mechanisms of uptake. Despite the large initial heat of adsorption, the CO2 uptake was fully reversible and the framework could be easily regenerated at 60°, enabling a cycling time of just 27 min with no loss of capacity over 72 adsorption/desorption cycles.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtFagtrzM&md5=eeb691022dc2b81537158452bbc9f11c
      25. 25
        (a) Xiang, S.-C.; Hu, S.-M.; Sheng, T.-L.; Chen, J.-S.; Wu, X.-T. Chem. - Eur. J. 2009, 15, 12496 DOI: 10.1002/chem.200900520
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25a
        Structural Diversity of Infinite 3d-4f Heterometallic Cluster Compounds Driven by Various Lanthanide Radii
        Xiang, Shengchang; Hu, Shengmin; Sheng, Tianlu; Chen, Jianshan; Wu, Xintao
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2009), 15 (45), 12496-12502, S12496/1-S12496/16CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The syntheses, structures, and characterization of six Ln3+-Cu2+-glycine (Hgly) coordination polymers were described. They represent three types of structures: (Ln = La (1), Pr (2), and Sm (3)) is a 1-dimensional catenarian polymer comprising [Ln2] nodes bridged by four cis-Cu(gly)2 linkers. [Ln2(H2O)6(L1)2(L2)2].6ClO4.4H2O [Ln = La(1), Pr (2), and Sm (3)] for type I; Na2[Eu6Cu22(OH)28(Hgly)4(gly)12(ClO4)(H2O)18](L3)3.23ClO4.28H2O (4) and [Dy6Cu22(OH)28(Hgly)4(gly)12(ClO4)(H2O)18](L3)3.21ClO4.2OH2O (5) for type II; and Na4[Er6Cu24(Hgly)2(gly)12(OH)30(ClO4)(H2O)22](L3)6.27ClO4.36H2O (6) for type III; in all of which L1, L2, and L3 are the cis-[Cu(gly)2], cis-[Cu(gly)2(H2O)], and trans-[Cu(gly)2], resp. Type II (Ln = Eu (4) and Dy (5)) is a 2-dimensional open framework with a 44-net, composed of novel [Ln6Cu22] cluster nodes linked by trans-Cu(gly)2 linkers. Also, the inner structures of the [Ln6Cu22] nodes, and the connection mode between the nodes and linkers are slightly different for 4 and 5. Type III (Ln = Er (6)) is a 3-dimensional open framework with a novel 36·418·53·6 topol., made up of [Er6Cu24] cluster nodes and trans-Cu(gly)2 linkers. The rich variety of the resulting structures owes itself mainly to the interselection between the dynamic control of metalloligands and cationic components. A transition from frequency dependence to frequency independence is obsd. in the field-induced magnetization lag for 1-3. The frequency dependence at low temps. may come from the antiferromagnetic Cu-Cu interaction through the [Ln2] nodes, whereas the frequency independence may be due to the disappearance of the antiferromagnetic Cu-Cu interaction at high temps.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVahu7jP&md5=70e13d5b526c83e99bd4e53401e19c01
        (b) Han, L.; Xu, L.-P.; Qin, L.; Zhao, W.-N.; Yan, X.-Z.; Yu, L. Cryst. Growth Des. 2013, 13, 4260 DOI: 10.1021/cg400454c
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25b
        Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Physical Properties of Two Noninterpenetrated Pillar-Layered Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on N,N'-Di(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide Pillar
        Han, Lei; Xu, Lan-Ping; Qin, Lan; Zhao, Wen-Na; Yan, Xiao-Zhi; Yu, Lei
        Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (10), 4260-4267CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Two 3-dimensional noninterpenetrated pillar-layered metal-org. frameworks were synthesized under solvothermal reactions based on a N,N'-di-(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide (DPNDI) pillar. Single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compd. [Co3(BDC)3(DPNDI)-(DMF)2]·2CH3CN (1) displays an eight-connected hex net with Schlaefli symbol 36·418·53·6 and consists of a DPNDI pillar and 2-dimensional 36 net layer that was constructed from a pinwheel trimetallic secondary building unit and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) linker. [Zn2(HFIPBB)2(DPNDI)]·8DMF (2) exhibits a six-connected mab net with Schlaefli symbol 44·610·8 and consists of a DPNDI pillar and 2-dimensional wavelike 44 net layer with helical channels that was constructed from a paddlewheel dimetallic secondary building unit and bent V-type 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoate) linker. The phase purity, thermal stability, and N2 adsorption/desorption of 1 and 2 were measured; the antiferromagnetic property of 1 as well as the photochromic phenomenon of 2 also were studied and discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXht1arsrzJ&md5=311e6337e64320a821cc95ada14b8a8e

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25c
        Solvent controlled assembly of four Mn(II)-2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate frameworks with rod-packing architectures and magnetic properties
        Tan, Yan-Xi; He, Yan-Ping; Zhang, Ying; Zheng, Yan-Jun; Zhang, Jian
        CrystEngComm (2013), 15 (30), 6009-6014CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        To study the role of solvents on the self-assembly of coordination frameworks, the reactions between MnCl2·4H2O and thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylate (thb) ligand in different solvents at 120° produced four new Mn-thb complexes. These Mn-thb frameworks, [Mn2(thb)2(pyro)3] (1, pyro = 2-pyrrolidinone), [Mn3(thb)3(pyro)3] (2), [Mn2(thb)2(DMA)2] (3, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), and [Mn2(thb)2(MeCO2)]·H2NMe2 (4), all use a rod-and-spacer assembly mode, but their rod-packing architectures are totally different because of the structure-directing effect of solvents. The topologies of 1, 2, 3 and 4 are novel (3,5)-connected net, hex, irl and sra, resp. Solvents with different conformations play a significant role in promoting the diversity of structures. The magnetic properties of 1, 2 and 3 also were studied.

        Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 7 DOI: 10.1107/S0021889802022112
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26
        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27a
        Microporous metal-organic frameworks for storage and separation of small hydrocarbons
        He, Yabing; Zhou, Wei; Krishna, Rajamani; Chen, Banglin
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (97), 11813-11831CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Hydrocarbons are very important energy resources and raw materials for some industrially important products and fine chems. There is a need for the discovery of better materials that offer enhanced capacities for safe storage of hydrocarbons. Furthermore, the development of improved sepn. technologies will lead to significant redn. in energy requirements and costs. In this feature article, we provide an overview of the current status of the emerging microporous metal-org. frameworks for the storage and sepn. of small hydrocarbons.

        27b
        A New Approach to Construct a Doubly Interpenetrated Microporous Metal-Organic Framework of Primitive Cubic Net for Highly Selective Sorption of Small Hydrocarbon Molecules
        Das, Madhab C.; Xu, Hui; Xiang, Sheng-Chang; Zhang, Zhang-Jing; Arman, Hadi D.; Qian, Guo-Dong; Chen, Bang-Lin
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2011), 17 (28), 7817-7822, S7817/1-S7817/4CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new approach was realized to construct a three-dimensional doubly interpenetrated cubic metal-org. framework Zn2(PBA)2(BDC)·(DMF)3(H2O)4 (UTSA-36, HPBA = 4-(4-pyridyl)benzoic acid, H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) through the self-assembly of the pyridylcarboxylate linker 4-(4-pyridyl)benzoate and bicarboxylate linker 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate with paddle-wheel [Zn2(COO)4]. The activated UTSA-36 a exhibits highly selective gas sorption of C2H6, C2H4 and C2H2 over CH4 with the Henry law's selectivities of 11 to 25 at 273-296 K attributed to the unique 3-dimensional intersected pore structure of ∼3.1 to 4.8 Å within the framework, indicating that UTSA-36 a is a potentially very useful and promising microporous material for such industrially important sepn. of C2 hydrocarbons over methane.

        27c
        Hydrocarbon Separations in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Herm, Zoey R.; Bloch, Eric D.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemistry of Materials (2014), 26 (1), 323-338CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. New materials capable of sepg. mixts. of satd., unsatd., and arom. hydrocarbons can enable more efficient industrial processes and cleaner energy. Outstanding challenges in hydrocarbon sepns. stem from the similar structures, properties, and reactivities of the mols. comprising many of these mixts. With high surface areas, tunable pore geometries, and adjustable surface functionality, metal-org. frameworks hold tremendous promise for effecting previously difficult or impossible sepns. In this review, the authors provide a comprehensive account of the metal-org. frameworks that were studied for hydrocarbon sepns. within the context of their potential relevance for sepg. various industrial alkane-, alkene-, and arom.-contg. mixts.

        28a
        High storage capacity and separation selectivity for C2 hydrocarbons over methane in the metal-organic framework Cu-TDPAT
        Liu, Kang; Ma, Dingxuan; Li, Baiyan; Li, Yi; Yao, Kexin; Zhang, Zhijuan; Han, Yu; Shi, Zhan
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2014), 2 (38), 15823-15828CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        We report on the storage capacity and sepn. selectivity of an rht-type metal-org. framework, Cu-TDPAT [TDPAT = 2,4,6-tris(3,5-dicarboxylphenylamino)-1,3,5-triazine], for C2 hydrocarbons over CH4. Henry's const., the isosteric heat of adsorption and the ideal adsorbed soln. theory selectivity were calcd. based on single-component sorption isotherms. Theor. calcns. indicate that both the open metal sites and the Lewis basic sites have strong interactions with the C2 mols. The combination of these two kinds of sites lead to the highest C2H2-CH4 selectivity of 127.1 as well as record high values for C2H4 adsorption enthalpies. To mimic real-world conditions, breakthrough expts. were conducted on an equimolar four-component mixt. contg. C2H2, C2H4, C2H6 and CH4 at room temp. and 1 atm pressure. Our results show that Cu-TDPAT is a promising candidate for CH4 capture and purifn.

The MOF displayed the highest C2H2/CH4 selectivity of 80.9 as well as record high C2H4 and C2H6 adsorption enthalpies.         Xu, Hui; He, Yabing; Zhang, Zhangjing; Xiang, Shengchang; Cai, Jianfeng; Cui, Yuanjing; Yang, Yu; Qian, Guodong; Chen, Banglin

        Three-dimensional pillar-layered copper(II) metal-organic framework with immobilized functional OH groups on pore surfaces for highly selective CO2/CH4 and C2H2/CH4 gas sorption at room temperature
        Chen, Zhenxia; Xiang, Shengchang; Arman, Hadi D.; Mondal, Jalal U.; Li, Peng; Zhao, Dongyuan; Chen, Banglin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2011), 50 (8), 3442-3446CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A new three-dimensional microporous metal-org. framework Cu(BDC-OH)(4,4'-bipy)·Gx (UTSA-15; H2BDC-OH = 2-hydroxy-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 4,4'-bipy =4,4'-bipyridine, G = guest mols.) with functional -OH groups on the pore surfaces was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. UTSA-15 features a three-dimensional structure having 2-dimensional intercrossed channels of ∼4.1 × 7.8 and 3.7 × 5.1 Å2, resp. The small pores and the functional -OH groups on the pore surfaces within the activated UTSA-15a have enabled their strong interactions with CO2 and C2H2 which were revealed in their large adsorption enthalpies of 39.5 and 40.6 kJ/mol, resp., highlighting UTSA-15a as the highly selective microporous metal-org. framework for the CO2/CH4 and C2H2/CH4 gas sepn. with sepn. selectivity of 24.2 and 55.6, resp., at 296 K.

        Metal-Organic Framework with Functional Amide Groups for Highly Selective Gas Separation
        Xiong, Shunshun; He, Yabing; Krishna, Rajamani; Chen, Banglin; Wang, Zhiyong

        Three-dimensional copper (II) metal-organic framework with open metal sites and anthracene nucleus for highly selective C2H2/CH4 and C2H2/CO2 gas separation at room temperature
        Duan, Xing; Cai, Jianfeng; Yu, Jiancan; Wu, Chuande; Cui, Yuanjing; Yang, Yu; Qian, Guodong
        Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2013), 181 (), 99-104CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
        A 3D microporous metal-org. framework Cu2(ADDI) (ZJU-26; H4ADDI = 5,5'-(anthracene-2,6-diyl) diisophthalic acid) with open metal sites and suitable pore space for their interactions with acetylene mols. was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. ZJU-26 reveals a three-dimensional structure having hexagonal pores of about 5.0 Å along the c axis and irregular pores of about 3.4 × 8.5 Å2 along the a or b axis. Due to the introduction of anthracene ring do significantly enlarge pore size along a/b axis and enhance the interaction between MOF and acetylene, ZJU-26 indicates large adsorption enthalpies of 32.7 kJ/mol for C2H2 and moderately high acetylene uptake of 84 cm-1/g, highlighting ZJU-26 as the highly selective microporous metal org. framework for the C2H2/CH4 and C2H2/CO2 gas sepn. with sepn. selectivity of 45.9 and 12.5 at room temp.

        Highly Selective Sorption of Small Hydrocarbons and Photocatalytic Properties of Three Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine Ligand
        Fu, Hong-Ru; Kang, Yao; Zhang, Jian
        Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (8), 4209-4214CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        By employing a tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (Tipa) ligand, three new metal-org. frameworks, [Zn2(Tipa)(4,4'-bpdc)1.5(H2O)(NO3)]·2(DMF)·H2O (1; 4,4'-bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), [Cd(Tipa)Cl2]·2(DMF)·H2O (2), and [Co(Tipa)Cl2(H2O)]·DMF·H2O (3), have been synthesized solvothermally. Compd. 1 features a three-dimensional (3D) pillared-layer structure with low band gap and interesting photocatalytic properties. Compd. 2 is a 2-fold interpenetrating (3,6)-connected porous framework, and it shows highly selective adsorption of C2H2, CO2, and C2H4 over CH4. Compd. 3 with honeycomb-like layers exhibits unusual 2D + 2D→ 3D polycatenation (2D = two-dimensional). The luminescent properties for these compds. were also investigated.

        Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (9), 4947-4953CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A three-dimensional triply interpenetrated mixed metal-org. framework, Zn2(BBA)2(CuPyen)·Gx (M'MOF-20; BBA = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylate; G = guest solvent mols.), of primitive cubic net was obtained through the solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2, biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid, and the salen precursor Cu(PyenH2)(NO3)2 by a metallo-ligand approach.         28j
        A microporous metal-organic framework with Lewis basic pyridyl sites for selective gas separation of C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 at room temperature
        Chen, Guohui; Zhang, Zhangjing; Xiang, Shengchang; Chen, Banglin

        Metastable Interwoven Mesoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        He, Yabing; Guo, Zhiyong; Xiang, Shengchang; Zhang, Zhangjing; Zhou, Wei; Fronczek, Frank R.; Parkin, Sean; Hyde, Stephen T.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (19), 11580-11584CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Three isostructural interwoven 3,4-connected mesoporous metal-org. frameworks of pto-a topol. [M3(BTN)2(H2O)3]·x(solv) (H3BTN = 6,6',6''-benzene-1,3,5-triyl-2,2',2''-trinaphthoic acid; solv = DMF or DEF) (UTSA-28-Cu, UTSA-28-Zn, and UTSA-28-Mn) were prepd. and structurally characterized. Because of their metastable nature, their gas sorption properties are highly dependent on the metal ions and activation profiles. The most stable acetone activated MOF, UTSA-28a-Cu, exhibits promising gas storage and sepn. capacities.

        High Separation Capacity and Selectivity of C2 Hydrocarbons over Methane within a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework at Room Temperature
        He, Yabing; Zhang, Zhangjing; Xiang, Shengchang; Wu, Hui; Fronczek, Frank R.; Zhou, Wei; Krishna, Rajamani; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (7), 1901-1904, S1901/1-S1901/25CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A newly prepd. copper org. framework [Cu3(H2L)(H2O)3]·3DEF·2.5H2O (H8L = 1,2,4,5-tetra(5-isophthalate)benzene; UTSA-34, UTSA = University of Texas at San Antonio) is constructed from the paddlewheel Cu2(CO2)4 secondary building units and the expanded octacarboxylate org. linkers as characterized by crystal structure anal. The permanent microporosities were established for both partially UTSA-34a and completely desolvated MOFs UTSA-34b and their C1 and C2 hydrocarbon sorption isotherms were measured to establish their potential for selective sepn. The authors further examd. the sepn. selectivity and capacity of UTSA-34b for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 binary mixts. at 296 K. Such high sepn. capacity and selectivity are attributed to the moderately high pore spaces within the framework to take up a large amt. of hydrocarbons and open Cu metal sites on the pore surfaces for their stronger interactions with C2H2 and C2H4.

        28u
        Metal-organic frameworks with potential for energy-efficient adsorptive separation of light hydrocarbons
        He, Yabing; Krishna, Rajamani; Chen, Banglin
        Energy & Environmental Science (2012), 5 (10), 9107-9120CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The sepn. of hydrocarbons with carbon nos. in the 1-3 range is of great significance in the purifn. of natural gas, prodn. of ethylene and propylene with the required 99.5%+ purity levels as feeds to polymn. reactors, and sepn. of ethyne from mixts. with ethylene. In this study the performances of a total of 19 different MOFs, carefully selected to span a wide range of functionalities, were evaluated for a variety of sepn. tasks. For all sepn. tasks investigated, MOFs with high d. of open metal sites, CoMOF-74, MgMOF-74, and FeMOF-74, have significantly better sepn. potential than other MOFs, ZIFs or zeolites that have been suggested in the literature. Of particular significance is the possibility offered by CoMOF-74, MgMOF-74, and FeMOF-74 for "fractionating" a 6-component CH4/C2H2/C2H4/C2H6/C3H6/C3H8 mixt. to yield individual pure components. Such sepns. are likely to have a significant industrial impact, resulting in significant energy savings when compared to current technologies that rely on distn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Thermodynamics of mixed-gas adsorption
        Myers, A. L.; Prausnitz, J. M.
        AIChE Journal (1965), 11 (1), 121-7CODEN: AICEAC; ISSN:0001-1541.
        Adsorption equil. for components in a gaseous mixt. can be calcd. by using only data for pure-component adsorption equil. at the same temp. for the same adsorbent. Predicted isotherms give good agreement with exptl. data for mixts. of CH4-C2H6 and of C2H4CO2 on activated C, and of CO-O2 and of C3H8-C3H6 on silica gel.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Adsorption of Gases on a Carbon Molecular Sieve Used for Air Separation: Linear Adsorptives as Probes for Kinetic Selectivity
        Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M.
        Langmuir (1999), 15 (9), 3206-3218CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
        The adsorption of oxygen, nitrogen, and a series of gases/vapors with linear structures (carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, acetylene and carbon disulfide) on a carbon mol. sieve typical of the materials used for air sepn. were studied over a range of temps. as a function of pressure in order to understand further the mechanism of air sepn. The ratios of the rate consts. (kO2/kN2) were typically 25 for the carbon mol. sieve used thereby demonstrating the mol. sieving characteristics. The adsorption kinetics obey a linear driving force (LDF) mass transfer model for most of the gases and exptl. conditions studied. However there were deviations from the LDF model for carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide. In the case of the former, the kinetic models ranged from LDF through a combined barrier resistance/diffusion model to Fickian diffusion depending on the exptl. conditions. The adsorption rate consts. increase exponentially with increasing surface coverage for the mols. which follow the LDF model. The barrier resistance kinetic consts. derived from the combined barrier resistance/diffusion model also have an exponential dependence on surface coverage. The results are discussed in terms of the mechanism of gas sepn. using carbon mol. sieves.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXitVags7k%253D&md5=05483b1753869f8ee0dc743fbc200391

        A luminescent microporous metal-organic framework for the fast and reversible detection of high explosives
        Lan, Anjian; Li, Kunhao; Wu, Haohan; Olson, David H.; Emge, Thomas J.; Ki, Woosoek; Hong, Maochun; Li, Jing
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (13), 2334-2338CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A highly luminescent microporous metal-org. framework, [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpee)] (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; bpee = 1,2-bipyridylethene), was prepd., characterized by X-ray crystallog., and found to be capable of very fast and reversible detection of the vapors of the nitroarom. explosive 2,4-dinitrotoluene and the plastic explosive taggant 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane through redox fluorescence quenching with unprecedented sensitivity.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkt1yqtb8%253D&md5=d02d4635719a0cae1e9d3a610a9645fb

        31b
        New Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Demonstrating Unique Selectivity for Detection of High Explosives and Aromatic Compounds
        Pramanik, Sanhita; Zheng, Chong; Zhang, Xiao; Emge, Thomas J.; Li, Jing
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (12), 4153-4155CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors report a highly luminescent metal-org. framework(MMOF), [Zn2(oba)2(bpy)]·DMA (I) H2oba is 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid); bpy is 4,4-bipyridine; DMA is N,N-dimethylacetamide, and its unique photoluminescence (PL) properties. the authors' studies on its guest-free form revealed unique fluorescence quenching and enhancement behavior upon exposure to the vapor of arom. compds. of group A with electron-withdrawing groups and group B with electron-donating groups, resp. The results demonstrate the exceptional ability of the guest-free form of I to selectively detect explosives of different types (e.g., arom. DNT vs. nonarom. or aliph. dimethyldinitrobutane). The origin of such an effect can be understood and explained from MO and band structure calcns. as well as a comparison of their electrochem. properties. Clearly, the nature of the analyte mols. and the electronic structure and porosity of the MMOF all play key roles in the emission properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXivVChtr8%253D&md5=ede93848686b709a17543172a6e7dc86

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31c
        Selective, Sensitive, and Reversible Detection of Vapor-Phase High Explosives via Two-Dimensional Mapping: A New Strategy for MOF-Based Sensors
        Hu, Zhichao; Pramanik, Sanhita; Tan, Kui; Zheng, Chong; Liu, Wei; Zhang, Xiao; Chabal, Yves J.; Li, Jing
        Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (10), 4204-4207CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        A new strategy is developed for the effective detection of high explosives in vapor phase by fluorescent metal-org. framework (MOF) sensors. Two structurally related and dynamic MOFs, (Zn)2(ndc)2P·xG [ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate; P = 1,2-bis-(4-pyridyl)-ethane (bpe) or 1,2-bis-(4-pyridyl)-ethylene (bpee); G = guest/solvent mol.], exhibit a two-dimensional signal response toward analytes of interest in the vapor phase, including arom. and aliph. high explosives (e.g., TNT and RDX). The interaction between analytes and the MOF is studied using in situ IR absorption spectroscopy and a DFT computational method.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        31d
        A Systematic Study of Fluorescence-Based Detection of Nitroexplosives and Other Aromatics in the Vapor Phase by Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Pramanik, Sanhita; Hu, Zhichao; Zhang, Xiao; Zheng, Chong; Kelly, Sean; Li, Jing
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2013), 19 (47), 15964-15971CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A systematic study is conducted on four microporous metal-org. framework compds. built on similar ligands but different structures, [Zn3(bpdc)3(bpy)]·4 DMF H2O (1), [Zn3(bpdc)3(2,2'dmbpy)]·4 DMF H2O (2), [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpe)]·2 DMF (3), and [Zn(bpdc)(bpe)]·DMF (4) (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine; 2,2'dmbpy = 2,2'-dimethyl-4,4'bipyridine; bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane; DMF=N,N'-DMF) to study their photoluminescence properties and sensing/detection behavior upon exposure to vapors of various arom. mols. (analytes) including nitroarom. explosives. All four compds. are capable of detecting these mols. in the vapor phase through fluorescence quenching or enhancement. Both electrochem. measurements and theor. calcns. were performed to analyze the analyte-MOF interactions, to explain the difference in signal response by different analytes, and to understand the mechanism of fluorescence quenching or enhancement obsd. in these systems. Compd. 3 also shows an emission frequency shift when exposed to benzene (BZ), chlorobenzene (ClBZ), and toluene (TO), which provides an addnl. variable for the identification of different analytes in the same category.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhs1WmsL7L&md5=7acb6b0cc5ffd0eaf736fd45ec07e83f
        (e) Hu, Z.-C.; Deibert, B. J.; Li, J. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2014, 43, 5815 DOI: 10.1039/C4CS00010B
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31e
        Luminescent metal-organic frameworks for chemical sensing and explosive detection
        Hu, Zhichao; Deibert, Benjamin J.; Li, Jing
        Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (16), 5815-5840CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a unique class of cryst. solids comprised of metal cations (or metal clusters) and org. ligands that have shown promise for a wide variety of applications. Over the past 15 years, research and development of these materials have become one of the most intensely and extensively pursued areas. A very interesting and well-investigated topic is their optical emission properties and related applications. Several reviews have provided a comprehensive overview covering many aspects of the subject up to 2011. This review intends to provide an update of work published since then and focuses on the photoluminescence (PL) properties of MOFs and their possible utility in chem. and biol. sensing and detection. The spectrum of this review includes the origin of luminescence in MOFs, the advantages of luminescent MOF (LMOF) based sensors, general strategies in designing sensory materials, and examples of various applications in sensing and detection.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1Slu7nL&md5=0369c383e7a6f4eeb65c73b2b66f1137
        (f) Hu, Z.-C.; Tan, K.; Lustig, W. P.; Wang, H.; Zhao, Y.-G.; Zheng, C.; Banerjee, D.; Emge, T. J.; Chabal, Y. J.; Li, J. Chem. Sci. 2014, 5, 4873 DOI: 10.1039/C4SC02157F
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31f
        Effective sensing of RDX via instant and selective detection of ketone vapors
        Hu, Zhichao; Tan, Kui; Lustig, William P.; Wang, Hao; Zhao, Yonggang; Zheng, Chong; Banerjee, Debasis; Emge, Thomas J.; Chabal, Yves J.; Li, Jing
        Chemical Science (2014), 5 (12), 4873-4877CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two new luminescent metal-org. frameworks (LMOFs) were synthesized and examd. for use as sensory materials. Very fast and effective sensing of RDX was achieved by vapor detection of a cyclic ketone used as a solvent in the prodn. of plastic explosives. The effects of porosity and electronic structure of the LMOFs on their sensing performance were evaluated. We demonstrate that the optimization of these two factors of an LMOF can significantly improve its sensitivity and selectivity. We also elucidate the importance of both electron and energy transfer processes on the fluorescence response of a sensory material.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVart7rF&md5=9540391b440f0cd3f819fc8332b50378
        (g) Banerjee, D.; Hu, Z.-C.; Li, J. Dalton Trans. 2014, 43, 10668 DOI: 10.1039/c4dt01196a
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31g
        Luminescent metal-organic frameworks as explosive sensors
        Banerjee, Debasis; Hu, Zhichao; Li, Jing
        Dalton Transactions (2014), 43 (28), 10668-10685CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal org. frameworks (MOFs) are of enormous current interest not only because of their fundamental importance but also due to their great potential for possible applications in gas storage and sepn., catalysis, imaging and sensing, to name a few. Recent studies on luminescent MOFs (LMOFs) in both bulk and nanoparticle forms have shown that these materials possess excellent luminescence emission properties that may be utilized to effectively detect high explosive substances. Developing highly sensitive, selective, fast-responding and fully reversible sensors for explosives' detection is in great demand for the homeland security, environmental safety and other humanitarian concerns. In this perspective article, the authors discuss the development, possible mechanism and future aspects of explosive sensing by LMOF materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtVKgs7%252FM&md5=0708993189db61a10702e51758f288c5
      32. 32
        (a) Cui, Y.; Yue, Y.; Qian, G.; Chen, B. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 1126 DOI: 10.1021/cr200101d
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32a
        Luminescent Functional Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Cui, Yuanjing; Yue, Yanfeng; Qian, Guodong; Chen, Banglin
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 1126-1162CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The authors discuss the title topic and applications such as LEDs and luminescent sensors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXnslKitr8%253D&md5=255200f12ee460fd90a29655c2b685dc
        (b) Nagarkar, S. S.; Joarder, B.; Chaudhari, A. K.; Mukherjee, S.; Ghosh, S. K. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2013, 52, 2881 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201208885
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32b
        Highly Selective Detection of Nitro Explosives by a Luminescent Metal-Organic Framework
        Nagarkar, Sanjog S.; Joarder, Biplab; Chaudhari, Abhijeet K.; Mukherjee, Soumya; Ghosh, Sujit K.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2013), 52 (10), 2881-2885CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The compd. exhibited selective detection of TNP, even in the presence of other nitro compds. in both aq. and org. soln. The selectivity is ascribed to electron and energy transfer mechanisms, as well as electrostatic interactions between TNP and the fluorophore. Despite the limited water stability and the toxicity of the reported CdII MOF, the results demonstrate a promising approach to achieve highly selective TNP sensing in MOFs. Thus, the luminescent porous MOFs with high water stability, large spectral overlap, and electrostatic interactions with TNP, could be promising candidates for practical TNP sensing by S. Ramachandra et al.(2011). Finally, the present study provides a new insight into the design of MOF-based explosive sensors, which are likely to be useful under more realistic conditions in the near future.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsV2itbg%253D&md5=9d8ae64e601d9265dec05c38b5fc3a91
        (c) Song, X.-Z.; Song, S.-Y.; Zhao, S.-N.; Hao, Z.-M.; Zhu, M.; Meng, X.; Wu, L.-L.; Zhang, H.-J. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2014, 24, 4034 DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201303986
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32c
        Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Transformation of a Europium(III) Metal-Organic Framework Producing a Multi-responsive Luminescent Sensor
        Song, Xue-Zhi; Song, Shu-Yan; Zhao, Shu-Na; Hao, Zhao-Min; Zhu, Min; Meng, Xing; Wu, Lan-Lan; Zhang, Hong-Jie
        Advanced Functional Materials (2014), 24 (26), 4034-4041CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A sensor with a red-emission signal is successfully obtained by the solvothermal reaction of Eu3+ and heterofunctional ligand bpydbH2 (4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl) dibenzoic acid), followed by terminal-ligand exchange in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. As a result of treatments both before and after the metal-org. framework formation, accessible Lewis-base sites and coordinated water mols. are successfully anchored onto the host material, and they act as signal transmission media for the recognition of analytes at the mol. level. This is the 1st reported sensor based on a metal-org. framework (MOF) with multi-responsive optical sensing properties. It is capable of sensing small org. mols. and inorg. ions, and unprecedentedly it can discriminate among the homologs and isomers of aliph. alcs. as well as detect highly explosive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) in water or in the vapor phase. This work highlights the practical application of luminescent MOFs as sensors, and it paves the way toward other multi-responsive sensors by demonstrating the incorporation of various functional groups into a single framework.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXks1Wqt70%253D&md5=1590a1dc92771564306f581f4155e753
      33. 33
        Zhang, Z.-J.; Xiang, S.-C.; Rao, X.; Zheng, Q.; Fronczek, F. R.; Qian, G.-D.; Chen, B. Chem. Commun. 2010, 46, 7205 DOI: 10.1039/c0cc01236j
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        A rod packing microporous metal-organic framework with open metal sites for selective guest sorption and sensing of nitrobenzene
        Zhang, Zhangjing; Xiang, Shengchang; Rao, Xingtang; Zheng, Qian; Fronczek, Frank R.; Qian, Guodong; Chen, Banglin
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2010), 46 (38), 7205-7207CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A microporous metal-org. framework [Zn4(OH)2(1,2,4-BTC)2] (1,2,4-BTC = Benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylate) with two immobilized open metal Zn2+ sites was obtained by solvothermal reaction, which exhibits highly selective guest sorption and sensing of nitrobenzene.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFOntLjM&md5=84c57e149577e5aa8ef4687f6a0f0ac3
